HEADLINE: Governor's Tax-Credit Plan Finds Unexpected Support

BYLINE: By JENNIFER MEDINA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to give some parents a $500 tax credit that could be used to pay for private or parochial school tuition is drawing some unexpected support in the Democratic-led State Assembly.
 The backing is coming from some legislators from New York City who say that they are tired of waiting for Mr. Pataki to increase aid to schools and say that they see the tax-credit plan as a way to help parents frustrated with the quality of their children's education.
''Of course, the priority is fixing the schools for the working poor and middle-income parents,'' said Karim Camara, a freshman assemblyman from Brooklyn who is the executive pastor at First Baptist Church of Crown Heights. ''That doesn't mean that we turn our back on the problems in the public schools or that we ignore the needs of parents with children in private and independent schools. We need to give parents options.'' 
 Some Democrats denounce the proposal, which has come under fierce attack from teachers unions, as a stealth voucher system that would encourage parents to remove their children from public schools. And they question why they should authorize a $400 million program that could help private schools while the governor has not spent more money on public education to comply with a court order that found that the state had shortchanged schoolchildren in New York City.
 Since the Republican-controlled State Senate has already embraced the concept of the tax credit plan, all eyes in Albany are on the Assembly. Many of the Assembly's supporters of the tax credit are also backing the governor's proposal to build more charter schools.
 Likewise, many of the most ardent opponents of the tax credit and charter school proposals say the plans would funnel money away from the public schools, which need it most.
 ''This is part of the governor's duck-and-cover approach to education,'' said Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick, Democrat of Manhattan. ''Rather than giving money elsewhere, how about providing the resources so that the system can be equitable?''
 The governor's proposal would allow parents who live in a district with at least one failing school to receive a tax credit of up to $500 per child on their personal income tax, if they earn less than $75,000. Parents who earn between $75,000 and $90,000 would receive more modest credits, between $125 and $375.
 Mr. Pataki and his aides have said that they are taking aim at families at the lower end of the economic ladder. Parents in 81 school districts, including all of New York City, would be eligible for the credit.
 Some Democrats in the Assembly have proposed a bill that would give an even larger tax credit -- up to $3,500 -- that could be used for private school tuition. Senator Martin J. Golden, Republican of Brooklyn, is sponsoring a similar bill in the State Senate.
 ''Too often the money goes to the system,'' said Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, the leader of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, who is sponsoring the legislation in the Assembly. ''Seldom does it go to the parents and the children.'' 
 The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said on Tuesday that he would consider the governor's proposal, adding that he did not consider it a voucher plan. Mr. Silver has not indicated whether he would support Mr. Lopez's bill, which was introduced last year.
 Several groups that represent private and parochial schools are supporting the governor's proposal and are lobbying to increase the proposed tax credit.
 ''For parents who already choose to send their children elsewhere, this gives them the ability to help afford tuition at an independent or religious school,'' said James Cultrara, the New York State Catholic Conference's education director.
 But Randi Weingarten, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, said lawmakers would be making a mistake by giving up precious revenue through the tax credit.
 ''There are some systemic solutions that are really needed, and this money could be spent so much better in the struggling schools,'' she said.
 The issue is so politically divisive that after Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, a Democrat running for governor, said on Wednesday that the tax credit could raise questions of constitutionality, he then clarified a day later.
 ''I support the idea of education tax credits,'' Mr. Spitzer said in a statement, adding that the state should first comply with the court order.
 Ruben Diaz Jr., Democrat of the Bronx, said he would consider supporting the proposal only if Mr. Pataki agreed to more than triple the amount of money allocated to New York City schools.
 ''It is inconceivable to me that anyone can say this is a way to increase dollars for education,'' Mr. Diaz said. ''Until we start spending money to our schools, we can't afford anything else.''

HEADLINE: At Citigroup, Earnings Rise With a Hitch

BYLINE: By JULIE CRESWELL and ERIC DASH

 BODY:
Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, said yesterday that earnings rose 30 percent in the fourth quarter, but that the rise was solely from the sale of its asset management business. 
 Stripping out that one-time gain of $2.1 billion, profits from continuing operations fell 3 percent, to $4.97 billion, or 98 cents a share, in the fourth quarter from a year ago as the bank contended with shifting interest rates and a spike in consumer bankruptcies. Analysts had been expecting the bank to earn a dollar a share in the quarter.
Disappointed by the results, investors pushed Citigroup's shares down more than 4 percent, to $45.69. 
 Citigroup's chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, said increased competition in several of its businesses and a narrowing in the gap between short-term and long-term interest rates in the United States had dampened earnings. He also said a number of one-time charges taken by the bank throughout the year had added up to a ''challenging'' environment in 2005. 
 ''This was a year where there were a lot of boulders running down the hill,'' Mr. Prince said in a conference call with Wall Street analysts. ''Hopefully, we hope not to have a lot of boulders running down the hill next year.''
 Citigroup's consumer-banking group, which includes its retail, lending and credit card operations, was hit particularly hard as profits plunged 23 percent, to $2.4 billion, in the quarter from year-ago levels. A spike in bankruptcy filings ahead of a new law that took effect in October caused Citigroup to take a $300 million pretax charge on United States credit cards. Another charge against revenues this quarter -- this one for $545 million -- related to a change in accounting for card reward programs.
 But some analysts cautioned that another factor affecting earnings in the quarter -- the flat yield curve in interest rates -- could remain in place for some time. 
 ''I don't anticipate the yield curve getting steeper in 2006 and I don't know why they should,'' said Andrew B. Collins, a bank analyst with Piper Jaffray. 
 Citigroup, like other banks, makes a big chunk of its revenue from borrowing money at low short-term rates and lending it to individuals and corporations at higher rates. Last year, as the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates, the gap between short- and long-term interest rates narrowed significantly.
 ''We feel like we had some headwinds this quarter,'' said Citigroup's chief financial officer, Sallie Krawcheck, in a conference call with reporters. ''The rate environment has been one. The bankruptcies have been one. But we feel very good about our underlying businesses and the investments we have been making.''
 Citigroup did have its bright spots. Profits in its corporate and investment banking arm rose 21 percent in the quarter on record levels of merger-advisory fees and strong equity-trading revenue, the bank said. 
 For Mr. Prince, who took over the helm of the bank in October 2003, last year was one of turmoil inside and outside the executive suite. Besides dealing with a public shake-up of his top lieutenants last summer, Mr. Prince has worked feverishly to overhaul the bank's internal controls and regain some credibility among investors and regulators.
 Late last year, Mr. Prince laid out a strategic plan that included broadening the retail banking presence in the United States; moving aggressively into fast-growing international markets, and perhaps even considering a small acquisition. The bank has held off on doing any major deals since March, when the Federal Reserve told it to get its internal controls in order after scandals in European trading markets and Citigroup's private banking operations in Japan.
 Citigroup also said yesterday that it had repurchased about $4.4 billion of its stock, or about 93 million shares, in the fourth quarter. Mr. Prince said, however, that the bank had no plans to continue buybacks at that pace this year.

HEADLINE: Another Rise In Confidence 

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Consumer confidence increased for a third month in January as an improving labor market and a mild winter left households with more money to spend. 
 The University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer sentiment rose to 93.4, from 91.5 in December. The index, which signals changes in consumer spending, increased to 81.5, from 80.2 last month.
 The University of Michigan's current conditions index, which reflects consumers' perceptions of their financial situation and whether it is a good time to buy big-ticket items like cars, rose to 112, from 109.1 last month. 
 ''The biggest supporting factor for this report is a healthy labor market,'' said Ellen Beeson Zentner, an economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York. ''Two of the main drivers for consumer confidence are the unemployment rate, which has been edging down, and job creation, which has been adequate.'' 
 Richard DeKaser, chief economist at the National City Corporation in Cleveland, said: ''We're seeing a recovery from the hurricane-induced pessimism of last summer. When the hurricanes started in late August and continued through late October, we saw a decline in confidence reflecting lowered economic expectations and the reality of higher energy prices. Those lowered expectations have proven too excessive.''

HEADLINE: Volkswagen Chairman Will Step Down

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
A high-stakes boardroom battle at Volkswagen ended in a truce Friday, as Ferdinand K. Piech, the company's chairman and an heir to the Porsche fortune, agreed to step down next year in return for two Porsche executives gaining seats on the board.
 Mr. Piech, a powerful figure who was once Volkswagen's chief executive, has been accused by shareholders and other board members of a conflict of interest since Porsche, the sports car maker controlled by his family, acquired 18.5 percent of Volkswagen's shares last fall. 
Porsche asserted that its investment entitled it to two seats on the Volkswagen board. Other directors objected, citing Mr. Piech's dual interests and saying that Porsche was trying to amass too much influence over Volkswagen, a company more than 10 times its size and Germany's largest carmaker.
 The dispute laid bare the web of interlocking ties among German companies, at times made all the closer by family holdings. It also raised troubling questions about corporate governance at Volkswagen, a far-flung automotive empire with public and private shareholders that has been rocked by a bribery and corruption scandal.
 Under an agreement reached between Porsche and Volkswagen's other major shareholder, the state of Lower Saxony, Porsche's chief executive, Wendelin Wiedeking, will join the board immediately, and its chief financial officer, Holger P. Harter, will be nominated for a seat in May.
 Mr. Piech, 68, will not stand for reelection when his contract expires in 2007, according to a spokesman for Porsche, Michael Baumann. Mr. Piech's successor will not come from Porsche or from Lower Saxony, Mr. Baumann said; those exclusions are intended to make the chairman a more neutral figure.
 Investors welcomed the agreement, though some still expressed concerns, especially since the Porsche executives would probably be under the sway of Mr. Piech.
 ''I personally felt that one representative would have been adequate,'' said William H. Browne, a managing director at Tweedy, Browne, an investment firm based in New York that manages Volkswagen shares and had campaigned to block the election of the Porsche executives.
 Still, Mr. Browne said, the departure of Mr. Piech would be helpful. ''Mr. Piech had a conflict,'' he said. ''To have him in there, with two other Porsche executives, would have tipped the scales.''
 Mr. Piech, who sealed the agreement in a meeting with Mr. Wiedeking and the prime minister of Lower Saxony, Christian Wulff, did not issue a statement and could not be reached for comment.
 When Porsche acquired the stake in Volkswagen in September, it said it was trying to protect the independence of one of its main partners. Volkswagen assembles much of Porsche's Cayenne sport utility vehicle, and the two companies are collaborating on hybrid gasoline-electric vehicles.
 Volkswagen has struggled in recent years, and it was viewed as a possible takeover target because a German law that shields it from unwanted suitors is in danger of being struck down in a European court.
 But the investment, experts say, was as much about history as economics. Porsche and Volkswagen have been intertwined since before World War II, when Mr. Piech's grandfather, Ferdinand Porsche, designed the Beetle at the behest of Hitler, who was searching for a ''people's car.''
 Ferdinand Porsche's son started the sports car company, which is the foundation of the Porsche and Piech family fortunes. Mr. Piech sits on the board of Porsche, but he made his name at Volkswagen, taking a company that was in deep trouble in 1993 and reviving it with eye-catching new models.
 ''The objective of his life is not just to make money, but to have influence and to follow the heritage of his grandfather,'' said Ferdinand Dudenhoffer, the director of the Center for Automotive Research in Gelsenkirchen.
 Among those who raised doubts about Porsche's investment was Mr. Wulff of Lower Saxony, who also sits on Volkswagen's board. He and other board members commissioned a report on the company's relationship with Porsche from J. P. Morgan, which criticized Mr. Piech and said no major Porsche shareholder or manager should get a board seat.
 A rumored boardroom revolt against Mr. Piech never materialized, however, attesting to his powerful position, particularly with Volkswagen's union workers. In November, Mr. Piech backed a former union official, Horst Neumann, to be Volkswagen's head of personnel, going against the wishes of the current chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder.
 The previous personnel chief resigned after a scandal involving the company's dealings with its worker representatives. 
 Porsche had to come to terms with Lower Saxony, analysts said, since it is the largest shareholder. Porsche also does not want to disrupt a radical overhaul of Volkswagen that is being led by Mr. Pischetsrieder and his chief lieutenant, Wolfgang Bernhard. In a vote of confidence, Volkswagen's board will extend Mr. Pischetsrieder's contract for five years.
 Volkswagen, which has been struggling to cut its labor costs in Germany, said Friday that it would assemble a new model in Portugal, starting in 2008. Volkswagen's board is also creating a committee to oversee the commercial relationship between Porsche and Volkswagen. Both companies have pledged to negotiate deals at arm's length.
 ''The key question now is whether Porsche will accelerate the restructuring program at Volkswagen,'' said Jens Schattner, an auto analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein in Frankfurt.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SUBJECT: SHAREHOLDERS (90%); EXECUTIVES (90%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (90%); BOARDS OF DIRECTORS (90%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (90%); MOTOR VEHICLES (89%); BOARD CHANGES (78%); AUTOMOBILE MFG (78%); TAKEOVERS (78%); FAMILY COMPANIES (78%); AUTOMAKERS (78%); AUTOMOTIVE MFG (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (77%); SPORT UTILITY VEHICLES (76%); CORRUPTION (76%); DIVESTITURES (73%); BRIBERY (71%); HYBRID VEHICLES (71%); AUTOMOTIVE FUELS (71%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (71%); ELECTIONS (71%); SCANDALS (71%); AUTOMOTIVE TECHNOLOGY (71%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (70%); PRIME MINISTERS (60%) Automobiles; Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations; Appointments and Executive Changes; Boards of Directors; Biographical Information; Automobiles; Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures

HEADLINE: In Seattle, Seahawks Rise, As Does Skyline, in Vision Of a Hometown Tycoon

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 20 

 BODY:
For years, Paul G. Allen was the invisible billionaire here, a tentative tycoon with a yacht longer than the football field where his Seattle Seahawks will play Sunday.
 But just as the Seahawks have shed years of obscurity in their first shot at the Super Bowl in more than two decades, Mr. Allen's prints appear everywhere as he remakes his hometown into an urban center to match his peripatetic passions.
As an investor, Mr. Allen, who founded Microsoft with Bill Gates, has had a kind of reverse Midas touch, losing billions on ill-fated ventures. But it is a different story in Seattle, which some here are calling Allentown, a nickname that cuts two ways, inciting both hope and fear. Seattle's major institutions are being drawn to Mr. Allen's vision of a city built around compact urban living and a biotech job engine that some city officials suggest could one day rival that of the Boeing Company, which still builds its planes here. 
 At a time when many cities are trying to find their footing in the global economy, Mr. Allen is redesigning whole parts of Seattle with the help of what could amount to almost a billion dollars in public investment. The city, known for airplanes, software and coffee, is moving swiftly into a role as a place whose monied elite promote philanthropy, global health and the life sciences -- gambling on a new economy that some worry may never materialize. 
 ''I'm just trying to do some things that are good for the city and have a positive return on investments,'' Mr. Allen, who will turn 53 on Saturday, said in an interview. 
 And while his portfolio has shrunk by about $10 billion from ventures elsewhere, according to independent analyses of his holdings, Forbes magazine pegs his wealth at $20 billion, and his Seattle properties are surging. 
 ''What's happened so far has exceeded my expectations,'' Mr. Allen said of his fast-moving Seattle developments in biotechnology, real estate, philanthropy, art and sports.
 Critics say Mr. Allen has become a social engineer with cranes and cash. 
 ''The job projections may be vastly overstated because no one really knows how big biotech will be, and we're still not sure how much this is going to cost the city,'' said Peter Steinbrueck, a Seattle City Council member who has known Mr. Allen since grade school.
 But Mr. Steinbrueck added, ''We're getting a very attractive urban neighborhood'' that most cities would jump at the chance to have. What bothers many Seattleites, he said, is the image of a very wealthy man controlling so much of the city.
 Of late, it is hard to avoid the reach of Mr. Allen's empire. The Seahawks' ''12th man flag,'' a tribute to the noise from fans that can upset the rhythm of the 11 opposing players on the field, flies atop the Space Needle. Mr. Allen has owned the team since 1997, and says few things now thrill him more than the chance to slap hands with middle-aged men in Seahawks blue hair and face paint.
 Down below, one of the biggest private urban makeovers in the country is briskly taking shape under Mr. Allen's hand. While his better-known partner in Microsoft wealth, Mr. Gates, is spending his fortune on reshaping the world, particularly global health and poverty, Mr. Allen has focused on his own backyard. 
 His company, Vulcan, is trying to build a biotech hub and housing for 10,000 or more. Nearby, researchers study frozen 56-day-old mice as part of the $100 million Allen Brain Atlas, an effort to go where no neuro-cartographers have gone before.
 And the $240 million museum he set up to honor the hometown hero Jimi Hendrix will take a step into the visual arts this spring, becoming -- for a time -- a showcase for rarely seen paintings by Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh and Picasso, among others. 
 And yet, despite the fact that Mr. Allen's influence has never been greater here, he remains an enigma. In the city where he grew up, Mr. Allen, a librarian's son, is little known, and his appearance on the football field and in the locker room at last week's Seahawks game caused the kind of stir usually reserved for Bigfoot sightings. 
 The mayor, Greg Nickels, has met Mr. Allen only once, said Deputy Mayor Tim Ceis. Stimson Bullitt, whose family has been a driving force in broadcasting, real estate and philanthropy here for nearly a century, said he did not know him. Most politicians, though they receive campaign contributions from Vulcan, say they have never met Mr. Allen.
 ''You hear all these stories from people who go to dinner at his house and they wait for him to arrive and then when he materializes, you don't know what door he came in from,'' said David Brewster, who founded Town Hall, Seattle's idea salon and culture center. ''He is a real interesting eccentric, and this town has always had a high tolerance for that sort of thing.''
 Mr. Allen, who has been in remission for Hodgkin's disease since 1985, has been a part of three big waves: the personal computer, the Internet and private space travel. (Vulcan financed the rocket that launched successfully in 2004, winning the Ansari X Prize.) For a man who owns a submarine and bought Captain Kirk's chair from ''Star Trek,'' it can seem like he is casting about, trying not to miss a bet.
 In the interview, Mr. Allen said he had no specific master plan for the city he was remaking, and he laughed at the idea that he was Carnegie in khakis. If anything, his idea is a back-to-the-future Seattle he remembers as a boy, where people got around the center of town by walking, combined with a New Urbanist setting. 
 In the South Lake Union area just off downtown, he plans to build 10 million square feet -- the rough equivalent of a dozen 50-story towers -- of condos, European-style alley-fronted homes, biotech and medical research facilities, hotels and retail space, with a trolley car connecting it all. The projects are ahead of schedule, with the cluster of condos built around a luxury hotel, Pan Pacific, and a Whole Foods store set to open later this year. 
 The words ''Rethink Urban'' and the eco-friendly phrases of ''sustainability'' and ''authenticity'' and ''urban sanctuaries'' are used in almost every presentation of what Mr. Allen is trying to do with the 60 acres he owns in South Lake Union.
 The South Lake Union plan also includes a retirement home, moderate-income apartments, a big new park, and medical research facilities drawn to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, a non-Vulcan property that moved to the area before Mr. Allen began to build.
 ''The thinking was to really have a place with activity going on all the time,'' said Ada M. Healey, the head of Vulcan real estate.
 Ms. Healey said South Beach in Miami Beach, the pedestrian shopping area in Santa Monica, Calif., and the Pearl District in Portland, Ore., were inspirations. 
 But each of those neighborhoods has been criticized as one-dimensional and empty of children or people from certain income groups. Ms. Healey said the demographic trends and costs of in-city living might be beyond Vulcan's ability to do much to attract families. 
 Mr. Allen said he ''pushed my people'' to come up with a new-century neighborhood, with green building principles and tight density, imagining a community of scientists who were never more than a few minutes stroll from their experiments.
 But the biotech idea, which many cities are pursuing, has been oversold, Councilman Nick Licata said, and ultimately may not be the kind of job producer worthy of substantial public investment. And Mr. Allen's experience in Portland, where he encouraged development around a sport complex he owned, ended in bankruptcy and hard feelings between city officials and Mr. Allen.
 Still, in Seattle, the Seahawks have taken the town by storm. The $430 million stadium where they play, Qwest Field, has been a fan favorite since it opened for football in 2002, after a substantial public investment and about $100 million from Mr. Allen. The owner asked his executives to try to re-create an atmosphere similar to the one Mr. Allen felt while attending University of Washington football games as a boy.
 ''For a sports team owner, you better enjoy this because it doesn't get any better,'' he said. 
 Coming on the heels of a dot-com bust that left Seattle leaders wondering about their next economic engine, the city approved most of what Mr. Allen asked for in the South Lake Union area, and the public investment could total $500 million to $1 billion, with infrastructure changes, city officials said. 
 ''Paul Allen is doing some very good things,'' Mr. Steinbrueck said, ''but it's tainted by the public image people have of him -- this very rich, flamboyant guy who hasn't grown up. He is seen as an enigmatic guy who wants to fulfill his fantasies from childhood.''

HEADLINE: Campaign May Be Down, but Weld Certainly Isn't

BYLINE: By PATRICK D. HEALY

 BODY:
According to the usual vital signs of political mortality, William F. Weld's candidacy for governor of New York might appear to be on life support right now.
 By his own admission, Mr. Weld, a former governor of Massachusetts, has been wounded by a federal investigation of a Kentucky college he once ran. Raising money has been a challenge, in turn, and, while some New York Republican leaders endorsed him early on, others are now iffy or worse. Alfonse M. D'Amato, the former senator, despises Mr. Weld, and he is saying so to anyone who will listen.
And any day now, a prominent Republican billionaire, Tom Golisano, will announce whether he is entering the governor's race; if he does, he is prepared to bury Mr. Weld with a Bloombergian avalanche of campaign commercials, his advisers say.
 Yet Mr. Weld is a singular sort -- a man who has never had a bad day, as Massachusetts politicians said about him. He is pursuing his campaign cheerily in spite of the challenges: drafting a ''Contract With New York,'' akin to Newt Gingrich's Contract With America, and considering creating a new political party based on tax cuts. 
 If Mr. Weld's self-confidence might seem like political spin, it is worth noting that a more objective politician has confidence in him, too: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, a Democrat who is running for governor. Within the Spitzer camp, Mr. Weld is seen as the Republican who could cause the attorney general the most problems, according to interviews with a dozen advisers and Democratic allies of Mr. Spitzer.
 ''It's fairly simple: Weld is likable and good with the media, he's smart, and he can debate well and is a former prosecutor,'' said one adviser to Mr. Spitzer, who, like the others, spoke on the condition of anonymity because there is no political gain in openly discussing a Republican candidate's strengths.
 ''Weld is the sort of Republican who does well in New York,'' said another adviser who has spoken to Mr. Spitzer about the Weld candidacy. ''He is a tax-cutter. He sounds very tough on crime. He's pro-hunting, pro-fishing, pro-environment. He is moderate to liberal on abortion and gay rights.
 ''He has aspects of Pataki, Bloomberg, Giuliani,'' the adviser continued, ''and these aspects can play well in the city and the suburbs and Long Island, and maybe parts of upstate.''
 Polls show that few New Yorkers know Mr. Weld at this point, and that Mr. Spitzer would beat him handily if the election were held today. But Mr. Weld says that as Republicans, independents and even Democrats get to know him better, more of them will prefer him to Mr. Spitzer. In the end, he says, voters will care more about his seven-year record in Massachusetts, where he cut taxes 19 times, than about his 10 months as the interim leader of a Kentucky institution, Decker College, which is now bankrupt.
 ''Aside from that issue -- it's been a real headache -- I don't see why I can't persuade anyone that I have the background to do good things here,'' Mr. Weld said at a breakfast with Albany Republicans on Tuesday.
 ''I'm a very happy campaigner,'' he said later in the day. ''It isn't that trouble follows me around -- I follow trouble! This is going to be a very fun race.''
 Enjoying himself and not taking setbacks too seriously, whether in politics or on his beloved squash court, are unusually dominant strands in the Weld DNA, according to Democrats and political observers who know him well. Mr. Weld's loss in the 1996 Senate race in Massachusetts, to John Kerry, was his political low point, but he bounced back the next year by relishing the political combat against a fellow Republican, Jesse Helms, then a senator, over Mr. Weld's nomination by President Clinton to be ambassador to Mexico. (Mr. Weld resigned as governor to pursue the job, but Mr. Helms largely scuttled the nomination.)
 ''Bill Weld loves a tremendous political challenge and should not be underestimated,'' said Cameron Kerry, a close political adviser to his brother, Senator Kerry, and a lawyer in Boston. ''With Weld, there's an intelligence to his political gamesmanship -- he has a great passion for figuring out how to master the game.''
 In New York, to be sure, Mr. Weld is still finding his way.
 At a dinner with 20 black Republicans in Harlem on Martin Luther King's Birthday, Mr. Weld impressed the crowd with his pledge to visit black churches and with his support for softening some New York drug laws, yet he struck some people there as shaky on the details of programs for affordable housing.
 The next day, in Albany, Mr. Weld impressed his Republican breakfast companions, and then two separate groups of business leaders, with his support for tax cuts and a statewide cap on property taxes. He said he was drafting a ''Contract With New York'' with a list of pledges: no new taxes, an indexed limit on state spending, a 2.5 percent cap on property tax increases, cuts in the number of public employees and changes to their pensions, and tort reform, among other items.
 Yet Mr. Weld also drew pointed questions about the problems at Decker College, his early departure as governor of Massachusetts and the threat of Mr. Golisano's money, should he run.
 Mr. Weld replied confidently (and said later that he was sure he could neutralize each issue); if anything, he seemed especially eager to go against Mr. Golisano in the Republican primary in September.
 ''It's an open, Wild West kind of primary -- I'll try to draw him into territory in which he's not that familiar,'' Mr. Weld said. ''I don't think he wins that primary, I think he's said too many nasty things about Republicans over the years.''
 Mr. Golisano, who declined this week to comment on his plans, ran against Gov. George E. Pataki in 1994, 1998 and 2002 and criticized the Republican leader sharply.
 Democrats, for their part, have been gunning for Mr. Weld. since he signaled his intention to run in August; the same day, a Spitzer aide urged reporters to talk to a gay-rights group that was critical of Mr. Weld's position on gay marriage (He supported it in Massachusetts but now opposes it for New York.) In recent weeks, New York Democratic Party officials -- who tend to act in Mr. Spitzer's interests -- have attacked Mr. Weld far more than they have any other Republican, mostly over the Decker College inquiry.
 Mr. Kerry, the senator's brother, said he saw similarities between the Kerry-Weld Senate race and the possible face-off this year between Mr. Spitzer and Mr. Weld.
 ''Bill Weld has always been very bright and charming, but when it came down to the issues that mattered most in 1996, people felt like he didn't really care,'' Mr. Kerry said. ''His lack of seriousness contrasted with John's.
 ''Eliot is a very smart guy and certainly a match for Bill Weld intellectually, and he also brings tremendous seriousness of purposes and engagement to the race, in a real contrast with Weld.''
 Mr. Weld, in an interview, thanked Mr. Kerry for the complimentary parts of his comments, and then asserted he was just as serious as the Democrats -- only differently.
 ''Eliot Spitzer was on Harvard Law Review -- he's obviously not chopped liver, but I would yield to no one on having a sense of purpose or seriousness of purpose,'' Mr. Weld said in an interview. ''The difficulty that some people have is that my purpose is Friedrich Hayek's and not Al Sharpton's.'' (Hayek was an Austrian economist who championed free-market capitalism.)
 Explaining that distinction, Mr. Weld said: ''My political gyroscope tells me it's very important to unleash the energies of everybody in society. And you don't achieve that purpose with a command-and-control, top-down, bureaucratized government. To me, the Reverend Sharpton represents government as the solution of first resort.''
 Mr. Sharpton said in an interview that he had not seen ''anything imaginative come from Mr. Weld, and he's run a flat campaign so far.''
 Still, Mr. Sharpton said he was struck by Mr. Weld's promise to visit black churches regularly this year.
 ''If he goes into the churches,'' Mr. Sharpton said, ''I think it'll be a different kind of campaign, and Bill Weld might prove to be a different kind of Republican.''

HEADLINE: If It Worked for Costa Rica . . .

BYLINE: By MICHELLE HIGGINS

 BODY:
RUNNING a country that has giant-winged bugs, toothy reptiles lurking in soupy water and enough humidity to frizz-out anyone's hair? No problem. You might have a great money-maker on your hands. 
 Eco-tourism -- travel that preserves the environment and promotes the welfare of local people -- continues to gain momentum. Impressed by the success of countries like Costa Rica and Ecuador, which have lured flocks of travelers for mountain treks and jungle safaris, a growing number of regions across the globe are turning to eco-tourism as a strategy for economic growth.
Omar Bongo, the president of Gabon, a developing country in west central Africa, has set aside about 10 percent of the country's landmass for 13 national parks. Green Visions, a tourism and environment protection company, based in Sarajevo, Bosnia-Herzegovina, is pioneering an eco-tourism development plan in Central Europe with ''green adventures'' that promote environmental principles and support local businesses. Even Greece, better known for its pumping night life and archaeological monuments, devotes a section of its national tourism Web site to ''Greek nature'' and eco-tourism. 
 Over the last four years, at least 48 countries, from Puerto Rico to Portugal, have created or started to define a national strategy for eco-tourism development, according to a 2004 eco-tourism report by Mintel International Group, a market-research company based in Britain. 
 Though eco-tourism has long conjured images of biodiversity hot spots in countries like Belize, parts of the United States are starting to embrace the trend too. For example, the Wisconsin Department of Tourism will begin testing a new certification program in March called Travel Green Wisconsin. Designed to encourage hotels and tour operators to reduce their environmental impact, the program is aimed at protecting the natural areas that play a significant role in defining the state as a tourist destination. If successful, the program will be rolled out statewide next year. 
 ''As a country we tend to think of eco-tourism as always over there,'' said John Ivanko, owner of Inn Serendipity, a bed-and-breakfast near Monroe, Wis., that has a solar-powered water-heating system and bathroom floor tiles made from recycled auto windshields. ''It doesn't necessarily have to be that way, especially when you have places like the Grand Canyon. We're just not thinking of it as much as a country.'' 
 For businesses, eco-friendly initiatives not only offer marketing advantages but can help with the bottom line. Hotels can cut costs by doing everything from installing energy-saving light bulbs to asking travelers to reuse their towels. And some 58.5 million U.S. travelers, or 38 percent, would pay more to use travel companies that strive to protect and preserve the environment, according to a study by the Travel Industry Association of America sponsored by National Geographic Traveler. Of those travelers, 61 percent said they would pay 5 to 10 percent more to use such companies. 
 However, selecting among the growing number of eco-friendly choices can be daunting, especially given the ever-broadening category, which now encompasses everything from basic campsites to high-end mountain lodges, lama trekking to motorcycle tours through the jungle. Enter the Sustainable Tourism Certification Network of the Americas -- a partnership of certification programs, environmental groups, government organizations and others, led by the Rainforest Alliance and the International Ecotourism Society -- which aims to promote sustainability and higher environmental and social standards for tourism. In September, the network designed a series of baseline criteria for certification to help generate credibility among members and promote local conservation. This year, the document will be put up for public consultation before being fully ratified. 
 ''Certification is a way for us to avoid green washing,'' the practice of promoting something as eco-tourism while behaving in an environmentally irresponsible way, said Ronald Sanabria, director of sustainable tourism at the Rainforest Alliance. ''Certification for us is a tool to avoid that and to ensure third-party assessments of requirements and really prove the company.''
 Within a few weeks, the Rainforest Alliance plans to introduce an online eco-index, www.eco-index.org/tourism, that will offer travelers a searchable database of hotels and tour operators that have been certified by a program member of the network.

HEADLINE: Rich in History and Natural Splendor

BYLINE: By DENNY LEE

 BODY:
For most of the recent past, what many Americans knew about Ethiopia was that it was a country of crushing poverty and a symbol of world hunger. But though that poverty still remains, Ethiopia has begun to find something of an economic lifeline in cultural tourism. Indeed, in a part of the continent not rich in historical remains, the country holds many of sub-Saharan Africa's most astonishing treasures, like the medieval cave churches at Lalibela, and the 1,700-year-old stone obelisks in the northern town of Axum. 
 Ethiopia, which calls itself the Land of the Queen of Sheba, also claims title to the Ark of the Covenant, the box of gold and acacia wood that is believed to have once contained the Ten Commandments. Ethiopian Christians say it is somewhere in the Church of St. Mary of Zion in Axum. (Abercrombie & Kent just started offering a 12-day tour for $3,000 that includes a visit to the church and other stops that trace the roots of Christianity as well as to the village of Falasha, home of the few remaining Ethiopian Jews.)
Although the country can't compete with Kenya or South Africa when it comes to big game, Ethiopia does have more than a dozen national parks, which are regarded to be among the most beautiful in the sub-Saharan region. The terrain ranges from the plateaus of the Simien highlands to the white-water rapids of the largely uninhabited Omo Valley.
 There are no luxury tented camps with teak floors and five-course dinners, but several tour operators are offering fly-in safaris into the Rift Valley, Mago National Park and other remote preserves.
 Visitors can spend the day spotting leopards and bird-watching, before being whisked back to their hotels in Addis Ababa, the bustling capital with its exotic night life, or Gonder, a slower-paced city invariably referred to as Africa's Camelot because of its many castles. DENNY LEE

Editors' Choice
Other recent books of particular interest
 ARTHUR AND GEORGE, by Julian Barnes. (Knopf, $24.95.) A metaphysical mystery starring Arthur (Conan Doyle), spiritual detective.
 THE PLACE YOU LOVE IS GONE: Progress Hits Home, by Melissa Holbrook Pierson. (Norton, $24.95.) This meditation on change blames New York City water rights for ruin upstate. 
 THE COLD WAR: A New History, by John Lewis Gaddis. (Penguin, $27.95.) A distinguished historian marvels that it ended short of hot war; he credits Reagan, Thatcher and John Paul II. 
 SMALL STEPS, by Louis Sachar. (Delacorte, $16.95.) This young adult novel (for ages 10 and up) picks up at the end of Sachar's immensely popular ''Holes,'' to which it is a quasi sequel.
 HERSHEY: Milton S. Hershey's Extraordinary Life of Wealth, Empire, and Utopian Dreams, by Michael D'Antonio. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A history of the candy king and the town he made. 
 JOSEPH SMITH: Rough Stone Rolling, by Richard Lyman Bushman.(Knopf, $35.) The Mormon prophet and his age in full color, by an academic historian who is himself a Mormon. 
 THE BLOOD STONE, by Jamila Gavin. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.) Gavin's latest historical novel for young adults (12 and up) features lots of 17th-century travel and a great diamond.
 GATE OF THE SUN, by Elias Khoury. (Archipelago, $26.) A rich Arabic novel of the Arab experience, full of pain but tempered by hope.
 SKINNER'S DRIFT, by Lisa Fugard. (Scribner, $25. A white farm family is the foreground of this novel; behind it, the sins of South Africa.
 CITIZEN: Jane Addams and the Struggle for Democracy, by Louise W. Knight. (University of Chicago, $35.) How a social reformer left paternalism for the progressivism that made her a national figure and, later, a Nobel laureate.
 JOURNALISTAS: 100 Years of the Best Writing and Reporting by Women Journalists, edited by Eleanor Mills with Kira Cochrane. (Carroll & Graf, paper, $14.95.) Plenty of first-class work, from Nelly Bly to now, with facts all in place.
 The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; LIVING IN/Stony Point, N.Y.; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 1598 words

HEADLINE: An Outpost With an Eye on Development

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
AS Buckberg Road climbs sharply up a historic mountainside in Stony Point -- with spectacular views of the Hudson River -- it unveils a storied tapestry of a northern Rockland County town where territorial battles have played a central role on more than one occasion.
 During the Revolutionary War, a battle plotted from one of the highest elevations in town was waged between the British and Continental armies.
Today, 227 years after Gen. George Washington and Brig. Gen. Anthony Wayne masterminded their successful assault against the enemy camped below, another kind of battle is being waged, this time between housing developers and the town's planning board.
 And, Buckberg Road, as the former dirt path was eventually named, has become a different kind of outpost: a new suburban frontier for buyers priced out of housing markets closer to New York City. 
 Thirty-five miles from Midtown Manhattan and a 60-mile-an-hour drive along the Palisades Interstate Parkway to the George Washington Bridge, Buckberg Road and other once-verdant mountainsides in Rockland's northernmost town these days are sprouting 5,000-square-foot homes instead of trees.
 Winding up the steep road, stone walls from previous centuries still mark out lots. Along the ascent, modest cabins and stately Victorians from the late 1800's and early 1900's give way to ranches and splits, built in the 1960's and 70's. Finally, at the peak of the mountain, newly built single-family homes sell for $925,000 and up and claim the choicest perch in town, a view of Tompkins Cove on the river's edge below. 
 The riverfront today is a place much changed since the Continental army fought there, with marinas now dotting the shoreline and chimney stacks of factories smoking across the way.
 Elsewhere in the 28-square-mile town, luxury homes in subdivisions similarly abut forests and open space, having radically altered the landscape in less than a decade.
 This surge in development recently prompted the town's newly elected supervisor, Philip A. Marino, to vow to turn the tide of development. 
 ''We built houses on the sides of mountains where we should never have permitted them, and we're paying for it now,'' Mr. Marino said. ''I want development slowed down.''
 Aware that overdevelopment could obliterate much of Stony Point's charm, Mr. Marino has encouraged planners to measure growth in terms of environmental outcomes, not just tax revenue.

What You'll Find
 Not everyone living in Stony Point is unhappy with the onrush of new housing. For residents like Victor and Helen Diaz, the 5,000-square-foot colonial in Stony Ridge Estates that they bought for $1.2 million last year, provided more house for the money than they could have purchased elsewhere in Rockland or in Westchester County, on the east side of the Hudson.
 Mr. Diaz, a mortgage consultant, said the family moved from a 3,000-square-foot contemporary with three bedrooms in Congers, another Rockland town, to the five-bedroom colonial in Stony Ridge Estates so that his children -- Victoria and Parisrae, 8-year-old twins; Vincent, 5; and Victor, 3 -- would have more room.
 ''The whole Congers area was getting too congested for us,'' Mr. Diaz said. ''We like the open spaces here.''
 When Stony Ridge Estates, one of the highest-priced subdivisions in Stony Point, was first being built five years ago, houses there sold for $750,000 and up, said Aldo Loria, an associate broker for Prudential Rand Realty, which is marketing the homes. Today, the houses start at $1.4 million. Meanwhile, the cost of land has escalated significantly, with typical lots of 0.75 to 1.5 acres in the subdivision now going for $500,000, Mr. Loria said.
 ''Before, a $1 million house in Stony Point was unheard of,'' he said. ''The town used to be considered the outskirts of Rockland County. Now it's fast becoming one of the county's most affluent areas. At the Meadows, a development next to Stony Ridge Estates -- both projects are being build by MBC Contractors, which is based in Stony Point -- prices for new houses start at $3 million.
 Elsewhere in the town, which includes the hamlet of Tomkins Cove, are Point and Jones Point, other luxury developments similarly altering wooded hillsides and former ski sites.
 There are also neighborhoods on side streets along Route 9A at the foot of the mountainside, where strip malls line the main thoroughfare. In contrast to the roadways that climb to higher elevations, many of the side streets near the center of town are lined with modest Capes, ranches, splits and colonials. There are no condominiums or co-ops in Stony Point, and except for one senior housing project, there are no rental apartment houses.

What You'll Pay
 The median sales price of a single-family home in Stony Point, a town of some 14,245 people, was $452,000 last year, up from $429,900 in 2004 and $377,500 in 2003, according to figures from the Rockland County Board of Realtors.
 ''It's been a steady increase,'' Mr. Loria said. ''Stony Point is moving up. It used to be that for $175,000 to $225,000, you could find a two- or three-bedroom Cape or bilevel in good condition. Now if you find anything for $300,000, it probably needs a lot of work. And forget about anything under that.''
 Currently near the top of the market, a newly built, 5,600-square-foot stucco residence with a two-story entrance, six bedrooms and four and a half baths is listed at $1.389 million in Stony Ridge Estates.
 In the middle range, a four-bedroom, three-bath colonial built in 1974 is listed at $689,000. At the lower end for single family homes, a three-bedroom, one-bath colonial that dates back to 1850 is on the market for $399,000.
 Property taxes, which are still relatively low compared with other areas, are expected to soar. Currently, the annual taxes on the colonial selling for $399,000 are $2,475; on the houses selling for $689,000, they are $7,744 a year. 
 But the town is in the process of settling a property tax dispute with the local power company, the Mirant Corporation, which could mean that the town would agree to pay rebates to Mirant or even lower its assessment. If that happens, said Mr. Marino, the supervisor, taxes would have to be raised elsewhere. ''We're not going to sugar-coat it,'' he said. ''It's going to be a bitter pill. The schools have told people to prepare for increases as high as 40 percent.''

What to Do
 Harriman State Park and Bear Mountain State Park, both of which are used for hiking and mountain biking, account for three-quarters of Stony Point's acreage. This time of year, Bear Mountain also offers ice skating and skiing; during the warmer months, places to swim and boat abound. Overnight accommodations are available at the Bear Mountain Inn, which overlooks Hessian Lake, with lakeside lodges offering a more rustic and private atmosphere. 
 Now part of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, the green area was saved in the early 1900's from development by E. H. Harriman, the president of the Union Pacific Railroad, and a group of wealthy businessmen who donated land and large sums of money to preserve the parkland.
 Several years ago, the town bought a section of Letchworth Village, formerly a state-owned residence for the mentally retarded, and turned it into a public golf course. 
 At the town-owned Riverfront Park, residents can fish, look for crabs and play volleyball. At Veterans Park, baseball fields and tennis courts are available. In summer, children can attend a town-sponsored day camp.
 For evening entertainment, restaurants abound in the area. There's also the Penguin Repertory Company, with theater performances beginning in late spring and running through October.

The Schools
 The Haverstraw-Stony Point Central School District offers kindergarten through Grade 5 in five elementary schools and Grades 6 to 8 at three middle schools. All public school students in Grade 9 through 12 attend North Rockland High School. There's also the Roman Catholic Immaculate Conception School for kindergarten through Grade 8.
 In a program called Project Advance, North Rockland High School offers courses in government, economics and statistics in association with Syracuse University. Through the program, students can earn transferable college credits, said Dennis Hand, the principal.
 Students taking the SAT tests last year scored an average of 506 on the verbal and 508 on the math sections. The state averages last year were 497 for verbal and 511 for math.

The Commute
 The Red & Tan Lines provide bus service, which takes about two hours from Stony Point to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown Manhattan, and costs $8.30 each way.
 But many residents prefer to drive straight down the Palisades Parkway to Manhattan via the George Washington Bridge. 

The History
 The earliest known inhabitants, long before the British and Dutch made their way up the Hudson, were Algonquin Indians, among them the Mohegans, the Munsees, Lenni Lenapes, Tappans, Hackensacks and the Sint-Sings. 
 The first European settlers were the Dutch, who settled in Tappan in Rockland County in the 1680's. By the 1770's, the river had become a busy commercial area.

What We Like
 Stony Point's greatest assets are its breathtaking views of the Hudson River from the higher elevations, and the colorful marina district down along the water's edge.

What We'd Change
 For major shopping or the larger chain restaurants, or to see a movie, Stony Point residents have to drive about 15 minutes to New City, the Palisades Center in West Nyack or other locations in Rockland County.

HEADLINE: Enter, Chopping Block Left 

BYLINE: By ARTHUR LUBOW

DATELINE: BERLIN 

 BODY:
AFTER a tortuous three-year search for a new general manager, the Berlin Philharmonic made an unexpected choice in July. Pamela Rosenberg, 60, will be the first woman and the first American to administer what is arguably the world's most revered orchestra. Even more surprising, Ms. Rosenberg has never worked for a symphony orchestra; her entire professional career has been in opera, culminating in the position of general director of the San Francisco Opera.
 Simon Rattle -- the chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, which will give four concerts at Carnegie Hall this week -- says he is not concerned. ''She expressed that worry,'' Sir Simon said. ''We find ourselves not worried. There will be areas that she will have to learn, but she is a very quick learn.'' 
Like a bride of Henry VIII, a new manager (or intendant, as the position is called) at the Berlin Philharmonic has cause for anxiety. The last one, Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, who arrived after a tempestuous two-year tenure at Carnegie Hall, lasted only a year in Berlin. The manager before him, Elmar Weingarten, was mysteriously forced out by Sir Simon's predecessor, Claudio Abbado. And in what remains the most notorious instance of a manager suffering for a chief conductor's sins, Peter Girth took the fall when the orchestra rebelled at Herbert von Karajan's insistence in 1982 that Sabine Meyer be appointed principal clarinetist.
 Governed by its players, the Berlin Philharmonic requires a manager who is neither too ineffectual nor too bossy. ''That's maybe why we are very lucky with a woman,'' said the cellist Jan Diesselhorst, an orchestra board member who served on the search committee. ''From their nature, they have the ability to be strong and weak.''
 In a more judicious assessment of gender advantages, Ms. Rosenberg herself said: ''I feel I'm a mother figure, motivating the company and being an ear. I spend a lot of time listening.''
 Although a native of California, Ms. Rosenberg will be returning to familiar cultural territory: she lived in Germany for three decades. After graduating from the University of California at Berkeley in 1966 as Pamela Henry, she enrolled in a summer program at Bayreuth, where she confirmed her passion for opera direction and found another life-altering love: Wolf Rosenberg, a German composer and critic 30 years her senior. They married and had twin sons.
 As a guide to an intellectually charged European milieu, Wolf Rosenberg excelled. He knew everyone and everything in the advanced musical circles of Germany. Along with a commitment to composition, he had a passionate interest in the human voice, possessing 3,000 78-r.p.m. recordings of early-20th-century opera singers. ''We went through them, and my ear became much more aware,'' Ms. Rosenberg said. ''He really made me critically able to listen.''
 He also introduced her to the groundbreaking conductor Michael Gielen, who gave her her first important job, at the Frankfurt Opera, in 1980. She advanced to become part of a four-person team running the house and, from there, to positions in Hamburg, Amsterdam and Stuttgart. Wolf Rosenberg died in 1995. Pamela Rosenberg was a co-director of the Stuttgart Opera when she was recruited to the San Francisco Opera, to start in September 2001.
 Once back in California, she realized how European she had become. In Germany, as in much of Europe, the arts receive heavy government subsidies, so an arts administrator needn't worry much about soliciting private donations or even selling tickets. In the United States, Ms. Rosenberg had to think differently.
 ''About 90 percent of your time is devoted to money and 10 percent to art,'' said Christopher Hahn, the artistic director of the Pittsburgh Opera, who previously worked in San Francisco.
 THE timing of Ms. Rosenberg's appointment complicated the challenge. An economic recession, especially acute in technology-driven San Francisco, was already unraveling the opera's fund-raising efforts. Then the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks discouraged potential ticket buyers from venturing out of their living rooms.
 ''The San Francisco Opera had been presented to me as the big golden plum with no financial problems,'' she said. ''It took a while for the realization of how deep this was to sink in.'' 
 The opera board, said its chairman, Franklin P. Johnson Jr., hired Ms. Rosenberg ''so that this company would take its place among the most exciting and innovative opera companies in the world.'' In many ways she succeeded in that mission. Her term was bracketed by two of the most notable American opera productions of the new century: a thrilling presentation of Olivier Messiaen's ''St.-Francois d'Assise,'' in September 2002, which was the first staging of this colossal work in the United States; and the premiere last fall of John Adams's ''Doctor Atomic,'' an opera that, like the woman who commissioned it, combines seriousness with audacity.
 But along with these successes, Ms. Rosenberg's tenure in San Francisco may have demonstrated the limits of the American way of making opera. In Germany, the orchestra players and stagehands are salaried government employees, available to an opera director almost as freely as pigment and canvas to a painter; their American counterparts are unionized hourly employees. Among her expensive innovations, Ms. Rosenberg introduced the European method of ''bauprobe,'' in which a model of the set is constructed for rehearsal purposes on the stage.
 ''That's where I saw my challenge, to get the thorough scenic results that you sometimes see in Europe,'' she said. ''Before, it was superficially slick stuff that was just sort of tossed on.''
 In the American opera world, schadenfreude is a more familiar German word than bauprobe. When the San Francisco Opera foundered financially early in Ms. Rosenberg's tenure, professionals at other companies shrugged. Stories circulated about flagrant disregard for deadlines, as with the designer for ''St.-Francois,'' who kept revising the leper's costume until the staff had to work overtime. Yet it is unlikely that the company could have achieved the new productions that galvanized audiences -- or for that matter, some that didn't -- without a rehearsal process that encouraged experimentation.
 Ms. Rosenberg opted not to renew her five-year contract. ''I decided I didn't want so much of my energy to have to go into what it goes into here,'' she said. ''I was having 16-hour days. For two years solid, I was coping with financial problems.''
 When she stepped down, she didn't know what would follow. She initially rebuffed the Berlin headhunter's overtures, even though being close to her two sons and two grandchildren in Germany enticed her. ''What I didn't want to do is just go in and be this administrative clog, or just a liaison between Simon and the orchestra,'' she said. Musicians in the search committee, and then Sir Simon himself, reassured her. 
 Now in his fourth season in Berlin since arriving from the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra, Sir Simon is gradually settling in. He has programmed more contemporary music, sandwiching it between traditional pieces on a bill. He is still feeling his way into the great Romantic repertory for which the orchestra is renowned. He has not tried to impose thematic coherence on the season's schedule as Ms. Rosenberg did in San Francisco, when she organized series of operas around subjects like the Faust legend or ''Women Outside Society.''
 ''The repertory is still the Birmingham stuff he did,'' said Manuel Brug, the music critic for Die Welt. ''There is nothing you see he really wants to do with them -- there is not a line. That is why people are waiting for an intendant.''
 Sir Simon says that the orchestra needs a manager ''willing to be authoritative within a democratic structure.'' Mr. Ohnesorg, as he had done at Carnegie Hall, craved the limelight. He quickly alienated the musicians with his peremptory decision-making.
 After he was forced out, the orchestra was shell-shocked. ''At the beginning they were so happy that Franz Xaver Ohnesorg left them that they said, 'Perhaps we don't need an intendant,' '' said Barbara Kisseler, the state secretary for culture in the Berlin Senate. ''They came to see this was a big error.''
 Even before she officially starts, on Aug. 1, Ms. Rosenberg is contemplating what she might accomplish in Berlin. Since the orchestra's hall, the Philharmonie, is (like Carnegie Hall) rented out many nights, she wonders if she might create greater coherence by developing ''programming streams'' for the Philharmonic's season and then encouraging visiting orchestras to present complementary bills.
 The Kulturforum neighborhood around the Philharmonie, which was at the edge of West Berlin, is near the heart of the reunited city, but it still feels like a marginal wasteland. Buses ferry suburbanites to the hall, then wait outside to take them home after the concert. ''It's so dead,'' Ms. Rosenberg said. ''If people could eat before the performance or have a drink, that would make a difference.''
 Like Sir Simon, Ms. Rosenberg is deeply interested in awakening a taste for classical music in young people. Before taking the Berlin job, she was trying to organize a musical kindergarten program throughout Europe and said that the Berlin Philharmonic would be ''an excellent launching pad.'' 
 COMPARED with other German cultural organizations, the Berlin Philharmonic is exceptionally profitable. Slightly less than half of its budget of 31 million euros ($37.6 million) is subsidized by the government. The rest comes from ticket sales and tours ($9.7 million each). In addition, it receives an annual corporate gift of $3.6 million from Deutsche Bank, earmarked for education and a glossy magazine. 
 But even the privileged Berlin Philharmonic sees bleaker days ahead. Although its concerts sell at an enviable 96 percent of capacity, the wait for a subscription, which two decades ago was six years, is now down to two years. Recording contracts, while still munificent by American standards, have been reduced by half over the last 20 years, to seven or eight annual releases. With state budgets contracting, other revenue sources will become more important.
 ''We are all on a learning curve, because we can no longer stick to that old manner of funding,'' said Tessen von Heydebreck, a managing director of Deutsche Bank. He foresees, he added, ''a sharp increase in sponsoring by private persons.''
 Fund-raising, marketing subscriptions, selling tickets: it would an unkind twist, if, by the end of her term in Berlin, Ms. Rosenberg found herself back where she was in San Francisco.


CORRECTION-DATE: January 22, 2006

 CORRECTION:
An article on Page 26 of Arts & Leisure today about Pamela Rosenberg, the new general manager of the Berlin Philharmonic, attributes a precedent to her incorrectly. Although Ms. Rosenberg is the first American-born administrative director, Wolfgang Stresemann was the first American in the post. Mr. Stresemann, who took American citizenship in 1945, held the position from 1959 to 1978 and from 1984 to 1985. The article also refers incorrectly to her professional career. It has not been solely in opera; she worked in theater early on.

HEADLINE: Positively East Fourth Street

 BODY:
The real estate boon and the East Village's rise as a desirable destination notwithstanding, New York City has just sold six buildings on East Fourth Street to a collection of arts groups for the bargain rate of $1 each. Depending on your point of view, the deal was anywhere from six years to more than a century in the making. J. Jennings Moss tells the tale of the bureaucratic tape. 


1882 -- The block gets an early taste of its arts future when the Yiddish play ''The Witch'' is produced at 66-68 East Fourth Street.

1959 -- New York City takes ownership of several buildings on the street, now part of an urban renewal area. Robert Moses' plan to demolish them is successfully opposed by the Cooper Square Committee.

1969 -- La MaMa Experimental Theater Club moves onto the street.

1974 -- La MaMa expands into a city-owned building with a month-to-month lease at below-market rents.

1990 -- Mayor David N. Dinkins's administration proposes 99-year leases to East Fourth Street arts groups, but the idea goes nowhere.

1992 -- New York Theater Workshop moves onto the block and buys its buildings, at 79 and 83 East Fourth Street.

1996 -- Ten nonprofit cultural groups now call the street home, including Downtown Art and the Choices Theater Project.

2000 -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration decides that the city should sell the buildings. The Fourth Arts Block, a new association of 13 nonprofit cultural and community groups, wants the four buildings its members occupy along with two vacant buildings and an empty lot.

A study urges creation of an East Fourth Street Arts District.

2001 -- City and arts group officials begin meeting to discuss sales of the buildings for a nominal fee. New York Theater Workshop joins the talks and eventually buys a city-owned property to use as a costume and set shop.

2003 -- The East Fourth Street Cultural District is born.

2004 -- Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council approve the sale. The price is $1 a building, but the arts groups have to find renovation money.

2005 -- In June, the Fourth Arts Block releases a benefit CD, including tracks from Moby, Philip Glass and Ani DiFranco, to help raise nearly $6 million.

In October, La MaMa closes on the La MaMa Annex at 66-68 East Fourth Street, site of ''The Witch'' in 1882.

2006 -- Six years after the transaction was first proposed, the Rod Rodgers Dance Company and the Duo Theater are the last to close on the building they share. The city has spent $3.05 million for renovations and pledges an additional $1.05 million.

HEADLINE: Developers Respond To the 'No Vacancy' Sign

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
A MARRIOTT RESIDENCE INN has officially opened in Manhattan, adding 357 guest rooms in a borough that has been depleted of 3,600 rooms since 1999, as many hotels have been converted to residential use. 
 The new Residence Inn, at the Avenue of the Americas and West 39th Street, is an extended-stay hotel, the first of its brand in Manhattan. It is on the leading edge of a wave of hotel development that could add as many as 6,000 rooms, or about 10 percent, to the supply over the next few years.
About 2,000 of those rooms are already under construction or conversion, according to a survey by PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. 
 The remaining 4,000 are in various stages of planning, and it is likely that some will not be completed, said Kirk Reed, a manager in the firm's hospitality and leisure practice. ''Probably some will fall out of the pipeline,'' he said.
 Nevertheless, this year is expected to be the first since 2002 that will show an increase in supply, after occupancy rates and average daily rental rates reached record levels last year. 
 According to the PricewaterhouseCoopers report, the occupancy rate of 86.4 percent in Manhattan in the third quarter of last year exceeded the previous peak of 85.4 percent, set in 2000. The average daily rate of $223.50 was about $12 above the previous peak in the third quarter of 2000. Nationwide, the average rate is below $100 a night.
 In many cases, the planned new projects are quite different from hotels built in Manhattan during earlier periods. Many are limited-service brands, like Holiday Inn Express and Courtyard by Marriott, and most are smaller than the average for a Manhattan hotel, which is 275 rooms. Many of the new developments will be in Lower Manhattan; traditionally, hotels have preferred locations in Midtown.
 But the high prices being paid for residences in Midtown, particularly near Central Park, have forced hotel developers to seek alternate sites where prices are less inflated. ''Hotels are being constructed in places like the Far West Side, Brooklyn and Queens,'' Mr. Reed said.
 Some of the new projects will include residential components as well as hotel rooms, mainly because the economics are more favorable. The Residence Inn, for example, will have 96 condo units on the top 10 floors, in addition to the hotel guest rooms, retail space and a parking garage.
 ''Projects like this are much easier to finance,'' said Harry Gross, chairman and chief executive of G Holdings, which built the Residence Inn and has other Marriott-brand hotels in the city. Selling condo units, besides renting hotel rooms, ''is a much quicker exit strategy because it refunds the equity invested in the project,'' he said.
 Mr. Gross said it took more than five years to put together the deal because of the complex land assembly. The structure is wrapped around a small synagogue and an office building on the Avenue of the Americas.
 The hotel and condos will be operated separately. In some other hotel-residential projects in Manhattan, like the Ritz-Carlton near Battery Park, hotel services are available to the residences. 
 The Residence Inn has its entrance at 1033 Avenue of the Americas, while the condo section, known as Bryant Park Tower, has its own entrance on 39th Street. 
 ''The hotel and the condo have their own heating and cooling systems,'' Mr. Gross said. The condominium units are designed to be ''small and utilitarian''; a typical unit is a 500-square-foot one-bedroom. The apartments are priced at $650,000 to $950,000; the median price for Manhattan condos, Mr. Gross said, is $1.2 million.
 The hotel portion of the project is designed for people on extended assignments in Midtown, possibly at the financial services and media companies in the new office towers near Times Square. The rooms are equipped with a full kitchen along with the usual bedroom and bathroom.
 Like most other hotels, the Residence Inn has room rates that vary by time of year and demand. Currently, a single night costs $275, with discounts for longer stays. 
 The art in the hotel's rooms is mostly of New York scenes. ''We commissioned artwork of things that can be seen from the hotel,'' Mr. Gross said.
 The rooms will be free of something else: tobacco residue. ''Residence Inn is the first Marriott brand to go all nonsmoking,'' he said.
 The typical stay is 7 to 30 days, Mr. Gross said, but five rooms have already been reserved for two-year periods. 
 The building is in the heart of the Garment District, and fashion shows are important business for the hotel. ''We get bookings from the fashion industry, which has two shows a month,'' Mr. Gross said.
 In Manhattan overall, construction of the planned thousands of hotel rooms would mean more competition for the owners and operators of existing properties, said Vijay Dandapani, chairman of the Hotel Association of New York. ''Any addition to supply cuts into business,'' he said, ''and if there is a downturn in 2007, it could be bad.''
 But he says history demonstrates that additional supply is eventually absorbed. ''In 1992, we had 53,000 rooms and that was far too many,'' he said. ''Occupancy fell to 63 percent, which is horrible. But eventually the business recovered.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: The building that houses the Marriott Residence Inn at the Avenue of the Americas and West 39th Street in Manhattan will have 96 condo units on the top 10 floors. The hotel, whose lobby is below left, has its own entrance, and its 357 rooms have full kitchens in addition to bedrooms and living rooms. Currently, the nightly rate is $275, with discounts for longer stays. (Photographs by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)
