HEADLINE: An Empty Robe

BYLINE: By THOMAS MALLON. 
Thomas Mallon's most recent novels are ''Bandbox'' and ''Two Moons.''

 BODY:
NICHOLAS MIRACULOUS
 The Amazing Career of the Redoubtable
 Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.
 By Michael Rosenthal.
 Illustrated. 528 pp. 
 Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $35.
IN her book ''Manhattan '45,'' Jan Morris imagined Columbia University's aging president, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler: ''So solemn, so imposing. It does not surprise us in the least to know that he holds 37 honorary degrees, that he has been decorated by 15 governments, that he is a member of 20 clubs. He has won the Nobel Peace Prize, of course. He has been a confidant of many presidents.'' 
 Butler's widely supposed sagacity prompted The New York Times to call him, on different occasions, ''the incarnation of the international mind'' and ''Prime Minister of the Republic of the Intellect,'' accolades that only add to the perplexity of his new biographer. How, wonders Michael Rosenthal, a professor of the humanities at Columbia, did Butler achieve such ''instant oblivion'' so quickly after his death in 1947? More to the point, a reader of Rosenthal's conscientious biography may end up asking how Butler, an empty robe far more ridiculous than ''miraculous'' (the book's subtitle derives from another of Butler's sobriquets), managed to hoodwink so many otherwise discerning observers for so many decades.
 An Anglophile philosopher with a phony posh accent, Butler was in fact, Rosenthal explains, a ''parvenu from Paterson.'' The Columbia College from which he took a bachelor's degree in 1882 was in those days an East Side institution of rote learning for local boys. Standards were low, and the library ''never remained open for longer than an hour and a half each morning,'' yet Butler felt inspired to serious grade-grubbing and all kinds of extra-curricular eager-beavering. The zealous undergraduate quickly proceeded to a Ph.D. and then a position as ''fellow and assistant'' in the department of philosophy, ethics and psychology. His lectures were often organized to the point of dullness, but Butler pushed himself to the fore with a notion that education itself might be a fit subject for study. He helped found Columbia's Teachers College in 1887 and served for several years as its president.
 During the 1890's, using the press, his personal connections and a rhetorical style as puffed as his own ambitions, Butler succeeded in a campaign to centralize the New York City public schools -- in its day, a reform position that shifted their control from Tammany Democrats to liberal-minded Republicans. Up in Morningside Heights, to which Columbia moved in 1897, Butler sided with those wishing to subordinate the undergraduate college within a first-class research university. In 1902, when this sea change was irretrievably underway, he succeeded the patrician Seth Low as the institution's 12th president.
 Butler began to recruit stars for his faculty, landing John Dewey but failing to get Henry James. In these days before tenure, lesser lights among the professoriate were bossed around by presidential will and whim. To establish all this, Rosenthal must reproduce some tiny tempests in dollhouse teacups, his protagonist hurling paper clips instead of thunderbolts, but each incident contributes to the reader's growing sense that Butler was less a self-made sage than a natural-born blowhard.
 His most creative involvement with the undergraduate college seems to have come in searching for ways to keeps its Jewish enrollment down. He considered having applicants take physicals that would ''find grounds to eliminate socially unappealing Jews smart enough to have passed the entrance examination,'' and throughout the 1930's he funneled Jewish students into an affiliated two-year college in Brooklyn. Its courses were ''taught largely by junior faculty members from Morningside Heights,'' and the dropout rate was enormous. When it closed after 10 years, Butler at last gave up on ''the Hebrew problem.''
 Rosenthal concedes his subject a ''deserved reputation as a dynamic university builder,'' but he also supplies the reader with plenty of presidential neglect and fecklessness. In the face of the university's ''severe undercapitalization,'' Butler was slow to adopt modern fund-raising techniques, and Columbia's successful partnership with Presbyterian Hospital came to pass only when he was removed from the negotiations. However lucrative the deal by which Columbia leased its 11 acres of Midtown property for the construction of Rockefeller Center, the university failed to protect the resulting rental income against inflation.
 From the start of his presidency, Butler sought influence over a much larger domain than the university's campus. He cemented a friendship with Theodore Roosevelt by insisting to readers of The Review of Reviews that the new chief executive was more than the wild-eyed charger up San Juan Hill. The college president later traveled west with Roosevelt and helped persuade him not to go forward with the creation of a national university in Washington. But the two men fell out over the issue of labor unions (Butler was particularly opposed to them for teachers), and after he criticized Roosevelt's plutocrat-pummeling special message to Congress in 1908, Butler felt the president's ''swift and brutal'' rejection, as if he himself were some junior poli-sci professor who'd tried the patience of University Hall.
 Certain that a skilled oligarchy was best suited to run an America he believed to be classless, Butler managed to remain a factor in Republican party politics. Hoping for a presidential nomination in 1920, he tried to sell himself not as an erudite educator but as the C.E.O. of a ''citizen factory.'' Even so, Republican delegates, on the attack against Woodrow Wilson, weren't about to offer the electorate a second college president in a row. Butler's contempt for the next three Republican presidents stimulated a crush on Mussolini, whom he visited on more than one occasion.
 Butler grabbed his own place on the international stage by playing up to Andrew Carnegie, whose Endowment for International Peace he was eventually asked to head. During the 1920's, he banged a loud drum for the Kellogg-Briand pact, which renounced war as a means of settling disputes. Butler saw the pact as ''the most stupendous and most revolutionary change that has ever taken place at any time in the history of the world.'' Less dizzily, Rosenthal chalks it up as a ''personally significant achievement'' for his subject; it did earn Butler, after some heavy campaigning supervised by himself, a trip to Stockholm for the Nobel. For years after, he tried to run the Carnegie Endowment with the same dictatorial fervor he brought to Columbia.
 With each passing decade, Butler continued to deliver a ''stupefying number of speeches . . . before every kind of commercial, political and academic audience.'' In 1933, one talk was direct-mailed to 9,000 individuals and publications. Rosenthal finds his subject in possession of a ''powerful narcissism'' and unencumbered by the ''self-doubt that occasionally assailed lesser souls.'' This particular lack was supplemented by Butler's near-sociopathic ''ability to believe in and even insist upon his own innocence.'' Naysaying jabs from Walter Lippmann, H. L. Mencken and others never made a dent in this ermine-trimmed nullity while he was being chauffeured from one testimonial to another or writing the autobiography whose only revealing phrase may have been its title, ''Across the Busy Years.''
 Busy, busy, busy. Butler was an essentially comic character, as entirely of his time as the gas-filled dirigible or ''The Man Who Came to Dinner.'' As a subject, he's probably better suited to the kind of 50-page takedown Lytton Strachey performed upon his eminent Victorians, and at roughly 10 times the length Rosenthal manages a more than judicious job. A reader suspects that the biographer endured a long, depressing surprise as the vacuity of his subject fully dawned, or dimmed, on him. Rosenthal makes a manful attempt to establish Butler's life as ''remarkable'' and his eclipse as ''unmerited,'' but in the case of this ''ultimate insider,'' it's hard to argue that posterity hasn't gotten things just right.

HEADLINE: An Exodus Driven By Home Prices

BYLINE: By FORD FESSENDEN and JOHN HOLL

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, if you had asked Stephen Joubert where he would be living in 2006, the last place he would probably have said was Florida. 
 Mr. Joubert and his wife and three children were living in a small three-bedroom house in Edison, looking for something bigger and hoping to find a house in the $500,000 to $600,000 range, he said.
As luck would have it, the 37-year-old Internet consultant landed a job that took him to Atlanta, and eventually to Orlando, where he had an epiphany: Florida was not just a bunch of old people any more, and he could buy a big house there for a lot less.
 He bought a 3,500-square-foot four-bedroom house with a three-car garage in Montverde, about 35 minutes from Walt Disney World, for $300,000. He earns less than the $80 an hour he commanded in New Jersey, but still feels as if he is ahead of the game. 
 ''I don't have the $165,000 income I was used to,'' Mr. Joubert said, ''but then again I don't have a $500,000 mortgage, so it's O.K.'' 
 A quest for affordable housing is driving an increasing number of young people, families and empty nesters from the New York suburbs to destinations near and far, a review of migration data by The New York Times shows.
 Mr. Joubert is part of one of the fastest-growing segments of the population, those who have made the exodus to central Florida. Nearly 10,000 taxpayers from the northern suburbs of New Jersey followed that path in 2004, a 66 percent increase over 1996. But the new emigres from New Jersey are also including destinations in gentrifying neighborhoods in Hudson County and New York City, exurban communities in Pennsylvania and upstate New York, and boomtowns throughout the Sun Belt.
 ''I do think a lot of this movement -- to Florida and the exurbs -- reflects, in part, a 'housing affordability' movement, or what I have sometimes termed a 'middle-class flight,' '' Prof. William Frey, a demographer at the University of Michigan, said in an e-mail message. ''They'll move as far out as eastern Pennsylvania, or northern Connecticut. But many are probably looking at Sun Belt markets, including central Florida, Georgia, North Carolina.''
 To be sure, not that there is any danger of the older suburbs emptying out. Thousands are still following the traditional migratory paths from New York to New Jersey as well as other inner-ring suburbs in Westchester County and on Long Island. And, of course, many couples continue to have children when they arrive, so the population is not declining.
 But more people are leaving northern New Jersey than are arriving, and that gap is growing. The net migration from the older suburban counties of Bergen, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Passaic, Somerset and Union Counties was 26,889 taxpayers in 2004, up 75 percent from 1996. Essex County, which has a combination of urban and suburban populations, was not included in the analysis.
 A review of Internal Revenue Service data on taxpayers who move from one address to another between tax years shows the following pattern from 1996 to 2004, the most recent year available:
 Increasing numbers of young people and empty nesters are migrating from those eight New Jersey counties to such urban areas as Hudson County, Brooklyn and even the Bronx. Interestingly, the number of households that moved from New Jersey to the Bronx in 2004 was 60 percent higher than 1996. 
 Increasing numbers of middle-class residents, particularly young families, are moving from older suburbs to the exurbs in Pennsylvania, southern New Jersey and Delaware. In addition, the number of taxpayers from suburban New Jersey who are moving to Berks County, Pa., the area around Reading -- 100 miles from Times Square -- has doubled since 1996. 
 Increasing numbers of residents are emigrating to more affordable suburbs and cities around the country, especially to central and northern Florida. Indeed, the rate of migration from the New Jersey suburbs to the Orlando area is up 80 percent over 1996. And these days, the migration is not dominated by retirees, who historically had headed to such coastal retirement destinations as St. Petersburg, Ft. Lauderdale and Palm Beach.
 Professor Frey wrote: ''There seems to be a widening out of the traditional city population (young people, minorities and immigrants) while suburbia moves further out. Pricey inner suburbs are spreading to mid-New Jersey and Connecticut, and affordable suburbs for young families are populating areas that had not previously been considered in New York's orbit.''

On the Move Again
 Andrew Kapochunas and his wife, Aileen Bassis, were born and raised in New York, but they moved to the suburbs -- first to Connecticut and then to Ridgewood -- to raise their children. The schools were good, and their two children had yards to play in.
 They moved to a ''transition house'' after the children went off to college -- large enough to accommodate the work of Ms. Bassis, an artist, and the children when they visited. But now that both children have graduated and are living on their own, the couple is moving again, this time to a loft in the Hamilton Park neighborhood in Jersey City.
 ''It will let us take advantage of a jazz concert or a reading or something that comes up at the spur-of-the-moment living,'' said Mr. Kapochunas, a 58-year-old staff consultant for Dun & Bradstreet. ''With Jersey City we think we're going to be able to do that. It's a quick conduit to Manhattan.''
 Mr. Kapochunas and Ms. Bassis are part of a growing wave of suburbanites returning to cities. The I.R.S. data show that these people tend to have smaller families than those moving to other destinations, and demographers say they are either the grown-up children of suburbia, or people who have completed the jobs they moved to suburbia to do -- in other words, empty nesters.
 ''They may have originally come from the boroughs to suburbia and now they want to go back to where there are more activities, and Manhattan is too expensive,'' said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Affairs at Rutgers University.
 The latest figures back up that observation. While migration from the suburbs to Manhattan is flat or even declining, the number of people moving to Hudson County and the outer boroughs of New York City is growing. 
 For instance, the number of people who left the eight suburban counties in northern New Jersey for such cities in Hudson County like Hoboken and Jersey City was up 34 percent in 2004 over the 1996 levels, and migration to the Bronx was up 60 percent. By contrast, the number of people moving to Manhattan was up only 8 percent in the same time period.
 ''We get some people who normally would be going to Harlem or Park Slope or Prospect Heights, and have found those places to be too expensive,'' said Glen Calderon, a real estate agent who sells property in the South Bronx. 

A Shift in Suburbia
 This wave is also likely to include many grown-up children of suburbia, a group that has always tended to leave, often returning to raise their own families. But these days, those 20- and 30-somethings find it even harder to afford houses in the suburbs.
 ''These are children who grew up in suburbia, but they can't afford to stay here because they can't afford our housing,'' said Pearl Kamer, an economist with a business group on Long Island called the Long Island Association. ''Many of them are single or newly married, they work in New York City or on the Island and they're moving to Queens and Brooklyn for lower-cost housing.'' 
 While suburbia has always tended to lose singles and young married couples, today it is seeing an increasing number of number of families with children leaving, the I.R.S. figures show. 
 What's more, the pattern has an income curve: The lower the income, the farther the move. Those with incomes below average, but not too far below, are moving one or two counties further out.
 ''It seems to me that there is a definite trend toward moving to the outer exurbs among families from all over the New York region,'' Professor Frey wrote. ''They appear to be low-income families at the early stage of the life cycle.''
 While the exurban trend has been noted by demographers for some time, and the I.R.S. data confirm that, a stream from the older suburbs as well as city dwellers are filling the new subdivisions in Pennsylvania and upstate New York.
 For instance, data show that Northampton and Lehigh Counties in Pennsylvania as well as Atlantic County in South Jersey are the fastest-growing destinations for residents of North Jersey. And even counties in Delaware are seeing a growing influx of families from the suburbs of North Jersey.
 ''Starter homes for today's young New Yorkers aren't in close-in Levittown (as in earlier generations) but really far out,'' Professor Frey wrote. 
 And increasingly, moving far from New York City for economic reasons entails leaving the region entirely. Indeed, the I.R.S. data show that the young families leaving the metropolitan area tend to have lower incomes, and demographers say they are in search of a combination of better pay, a lower cost of living and a warmer climate. Not surprisingly, the fastest-growing destinations are in central Florida.
 Yes, the trail to from New York to Florida was blazed by retirees in past decades, and that flow continues today. But more and more, the flow is enhanced by couples with young children. Migration to St. Petersburg, a notable destination for New Jersey taxpayers with low family size -- in other words, retirees -- has fallen by 20 percent. But the flow to Tampa, a neighboring city, is up 67 percent.
 ''There have been so many immigrants from the Northeast over the years, mainly retirees, that they brought the Northeast with them,'' Professor Hughes said. ''Central Florida has been reinvented as the Northeast without snow.'' 
 For now, the economy is good, and although the jobs do not pay as well, the cost of living is also lower.
 ''Florida is now a very diversified economy,'' Professor Hughes said. ''It's not too different from the Northeast economy.''
 That contrast in living costs can be especially stark for residents of the suburbs surrounding New York, who are among the leading contributors to the area's population.
 ''The 'new' New York-to-Florida migration is not just old-timers but younger and middle-age families to central Florida,'' Professor Frey says. ''These along with movers to other Sun Belt suburbs represent a new extended version of suburbanization: people in quest of a suburban lifestyle who cannot afford the suburbs within the New York area, or deal with the long commute to the exurbs.''
 Or, as Mr. Joubert put it, ''Compared to New Jersey, they are practically giving houses away down here.''

 Chris Livingston for The New York Times

HEADLINE: Historic Estate Is at the Heart of an Open-Space Battle

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN 

 BODY:
THERE'S a battle being waged in this historic county seat, where Washington slept and Alfred Vail burned the midnight oil perfecting the telegraph. 
 The battleground is a six-acre estate linked to Mr. Vail's design and construction of the two transmitters that he and Samuel F. B. Morse used to send the first telegraph signal in 1844.
The fight is over a proposal to build 26 town houses on the estate, the last significant swath of open space here and part of the same Speedwell Village Historic District that includes the workshop where Mr. Vail did his civilization-altering work. The estate, which includes a 17-room mansion known as Willow Hall, belonged to Mr. Vail's brother, George, who officials say built it in 1848 with profits from his investment in the telegraph.
 ''It is inappropriate to build modern construction on the site,'' said Marion Harris, chairwoman of the Morristown Historic Preservation Commission, which opposes the town houses. 
 The proposal, submitted by K & K Development of Millburn and now pending before the Morristown Board of Adjustment, would actually preserve the mansion. But Ms. Harris and others say that building three town house clusters on the surrounding acreage would corrupt the historic integrity of the Willow Hall site, which overlooks the remains of the Speedwell ironworks. 
 The ironworks was founded by the Vail family in the early 19th century, and historic in its own right as a manufacturer of parts for the nation's first railroads. The entire Speedwell Village district, including Willow Hall, the Factory and other buildings or ruins clustered around Route 202 near Speedwell Lake, are on the New Jersey and National Register of Historic Places, said Mark Sutherland, a superintendent for the Morris County Park Commission, which operates a visitors center there. Willow Hall is privately owned.
 Morristown, where Washington made his headquarters at Jockey Hollow for part of the Revolutionary War, is a three-square-mile town of about 19,000 residents and is the seat of Morris County. Much of its land is occupied by tax-exempt country offices and nonprofit organizations, and supporters of the town house plan say Morristown needs the tax revenues the project would generate, estimated to total more than $500,000 annually. Proponents also welcome the jobs and other local economic activity that the project's construction and new residents would generate. 
 ''Why are you giving these developers such a hard time, when our town's so desperate for ratables?'' said Mark Axelrod, a local businessman who has circulated a flier headed ''Change Is Inevitable. The Choice Is Yours,'' urging residents to support the project. ''When Willow Hall came along, I thought, 'This guy's willing to save the mansion, he's willing to put an easement around Speedwell Lake.' And it just seemed to me like this was a great opportunity.''
 The developer is seeking variances from the Board of Adjustment to build town houses on property zoned for single-family homes, and to encroach on an artificial slope. A hearing before the board is scheduled to continue on Wednesday, although a decision is not expected for some time. 
 An unusual aspect of the proposal by K & K would establish a fund financed by the town house owners' condominium association to maintain the landscaping immediately surrounding the house, said James Cavanaugh, a former Essex County freeholder hired as the project manager by K & K. The town houses would have design elements alluding to the architecture and materials of the stone house.
 Mr. Cavanaugh said the town houses would be priced at about $800,000 and marketed to older couples without children, and therefore have little effect on the local school district or municipal budget.
 But in addition to opposition from the historic commission, a group known as the Cutler Park Neighborhood opposes the project because of its proposed density and potential environmental and historical impact. 
 ''This is the last six acres in Morristown proper, the last open space,'' said a member of the group, Myra McCready, a retired theater producer who moved to town from Stamford, Conn., two years ago. ''As much as I like new ratables and new residential opportunities as much as the next person, I think it's important that we preserve this space.''
 The county parks commission tried to buy Willow Hall. But its owner, Frederick Stradtman, a 76-year-old retired public-school teacher who inherited the estate from his aunt, said the county's offer was less than half of the $3.2 million that K & K agreed to pay him -- contingent on the town house project's approval. Mr. Stradtman said he was not being greedy. He said he and his aunt, Pauline Stradtman, who died in 1985, had agreed that the proceeds from Willow Hall's sale would finance charities including a scholarship she founded for students of the Moody Bible Institute in Chicago.
 ''The county had first choice, but the offer they came in with was just ridiculous,'' Mr. Stradtman said. 
 Samantha Rothman, a member of the town Environmental Commission, said the project would erode the steep slope down to Speedwell Lake, cut down several trees and disrupt a habitat of the endangered wood turtle. 
 Mr. Cavanaugh said that measures would be taken to prevent erosion and protect the habitat, and that only a few trees would be felled. He emphasized that the house would still be visible from Speedwell Avenue. 
 He said he is confounded by the opposition, because the proposal would achieve the dual goals of preserving the mansion and providing local revenues. 
 ''If you develop this for single families, the road would come right through the house, and you'd lose the house,'' he said during an interview at Willow Hall, whose grandeur is slightly faded but still apparent in its 12-foot ceilings and three-story sky-lit stairwell. 
 In addition, Mr. Cavanaugh said an easement would also be granted for a public walkway on the Willow Hall side of the lake, which would be linked to a public path already on the lake's far side, a wooded hillside now occupied by a town park that includes the stone ruins of buildings that were once part of the ironworks.
 The estate pays about $59,000 a year in property taxes, triple what Mr. Stradtman paid before a townwide revaluation in 2004, although he had put the house on the market before the revaluation, and he said taxes had nothing to do with his plans to sell and move to a warmer climate. Still, the town's rising taxes have fueled support for the town house project, particularly as other development proposals have been slow to materialize, including a 66-unit residential project on Court Street and a mixed-used development on the old Epstein's department store site fronting Morristown's famous village green. 
 Morristown's mayor, Donald Cresitello, a friend of Mr. Cavanaugh's, said he would prefer that the mansion be preserved without the town houses. But, he said, ''In defense of Jimmy's project, it does save the house.'' 
 Jack Schrier, a Morris County freeholder who is chairman of the freeholder board's committee overseeing open space and historic preservation, said the county might still be interested in buying Willow Hall if the K & K application is rejected. But with limited resources, he added, ''You can't preserve everything.''

HEADLINE: In New York City, Still Going Strong

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
THE economy of New York City is a bit of a mystery, even at times to the experts. Battered by the 2001 terrorist attack, high inflation and Wall Street employment losses that have never recovered, it nevertheless remains strong, with flashes of downright brawniness.
 During 2005, the city's unemployment hovered around 6 percent, slightly above the national average, and an improvement over the 6.8 percent rate the year before. Wall Street bonuses continue to skyrocket, leading to an 8.7 percent increase in personal income tax revenue in the third quarter of 2005 over the same period a year earlier, according to the city comptroller's office, and a 25 percent spike in capital gains taxes, all of which line the city's coffers. 
 As for the real estate market, the amount of vacant commercial space has fallen in recent months, and in the last quarter of 2005, apartment sale prices remained above the levels of a year ago, even as sales slowed. 
 In a sign of continued confidence in the city's future fortunes, the number of building permits issued bythe city in the first nine months of 2005 -- the latest figures available from the comptroller's office -- rose 7 percent from the same period in 2004, which meansthat people are still building in anticipation of new-home sales. 
 ''I'd characterize the local economy as relatively strong over all,'' said Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. ''Commercial real estate, the securities industry, and thus personalincome and tax revenues, and, to a lesserextent, the labor market are all showing signs of strengthening. The housing market has shown some signs of cooling recently, but remains pretty strong in terms of levels.''
 The questions that economists, elected officials and others who spend their professional lives gazing into the crystal ball of economics ponder most are: what engine drives the economy, and how long can it last? 
 These questions are particularly urgent at a time of high heating costs nationwide and high inflation locally, and when many sectors of the economy, like professional services, continue to show sluggish growth or, like construction, have posted losses. In addition, many jobs lost on Wall Street at the beginning of the decade are not expected to return. 
 But New York is often at odds with the rest of the nation, or at least finds itself at the extremes of national trends, with an ever-frothy real estate market, a tourism industry that depends heavily on foreign visitors and a dependence on the mercurial ways of Wall Street.
 The improvement in the city's economy last year was in large part a result of the weak American dollar, which made New York a better bargain for foreign visitors and led to a boom in tourism, and to employment gains in other major industries, like health care and education. During the first 10 months of last year, for instance, the number of jobs in the leisure and hospitality sector grew 3 percent over 2004, while jobs in health and education services rose 2.5 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
 The continued decrease in crime has further increased tourism and the willingness of New Yorkers to buy or rent homes in a variety of city neighborhoods, keeping prices high.
 But nipping at the heels of all this success is continued inflation, which New Yorkers feel acutely. Consumer prices in New York rose last year about 4.1 percent, above the nation's 3.8 percent, led by the costs of food, housing and gas. Inflation can be felt in every nook of the city, in the deli counters, the rental offices of apartment buildings and the movie theaters. 
 There are signs that inflation is makingit hard for some people and businesses to stay in New York. The creative fields -- which make up roughly 10 percent of the city's work force -- are particularly affected. 
 For example, from 2001 to 2004, the number of jobs in New York's motion picture and sound recording industries declined by 36 percent, according to a recent report by the Center for an Urban Future, a research group in Manhattan that analyzes urban policy issues. 
 The report also pointed out that 20 years ago, New York was the headquarters for half of the world's advertising agencies, but is now home to fewer than a third. Scores of artists have left the city in recent years for cheaper cities like Philadelphia and Seattle, undermining New York's dominance in the fine and commercial arts.
 And while the city has continued torecover from Sept. 11 better than economists and officials predicted at the time,the pace of that recovery has lagged be-hind the nation's, with slower growth in economic output and a slower rise in payroll jobs. 
 Further, while available office space dwindles, the number of people working in those offices has not increased by a corresponding amount, puzzling some economists. ''I still don't know why we haven't added more jobs in recent months, especially given how well the commercial real estate market has done,'' said Barbara Byrne Denham, an economist at Jones Lang LaSalle, a real estate firm. 
 ''Net absorption, which measures the increase in occupied office space, has been strong, but office job growth has been tepid,'' she said. ''This is inconsistent: companies are leasing space but not adding enough jobs to fill the space.'' Another New York mystery.
 While New York has worked hard to diversify its economic base, almighty Wall Street still dictates much of its fortunes. The sleuths of the economy remain as they do at the beginning of every calendar year: skeptical. 
 In a report by the city's comptroller office released in December, the authors wrote: ''The cost pressures and risks facing the national economy are of concern forthe city as well. Since the city's economyis highly dependent on the financial sector, the impact of higher interest rates will be amplified locally. The city's economy is likely therefore to grow more slowly in 2006, despite generally positive leading indicators.''

HEADLINE: Retraining for Silicon Alley

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
HUGO COELLO was skilled in a basic software program for database management, enabling him to work as a database administrator for a nonprofit group. That skill later got him a job with an information technology consulting company, but to be more valuable to his employer, he needed to master software for creating and managing larger databases.
 Roberto Ruggiero and Anika Reynolds majored in computer science in college. Mr. Ruggiero could not get a job in software operations, and Ms. Reynolds wanted to learn a major programming language that her college courses did not cover before she started her job search. All three found the same solution: training courses offered by the New York Software Industry Association, the leading trade group for software, information technology and Web development companies in the New York City area. 
The free courses, financed by a grant of nearly $3 million from the United States Labor Department, have been offered for two and a half years as part of an effort to help Silicon Alley -- the city's slice of the information technology industry -- rebound from the battering it has suffered in recent years. 
 The blows were inflicted by the bursting of the dot-com bubble in 2000, the attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001 -- which hurt Silicon Alley even more than it did the industry elsewhere -- and the outsourcing of technology jobs abroad.
 ''There was a serious downturn,'' said Bruce E. Bernstein, president of the software trade group. But, he added, the industry in New York ''never went away, and now it's coming back.''
 Citing developments in areas like blogging and Web video, Mr. Bernstein said, ''New technologies and new sorts of services on the Internet are giving rise to new companies doing new things.'' The training program, he said, is intended to help the revival by enhancing the abilities of job seekers and advancing the skills of current workers who are challenged by constant change. ''The training program is part of an effort to keep the New York region as competitive as possible,'' not only with China and India, he said, but with high-tech hubs like Boston and northern Virginia.
 After growing an average of about 15 percent a year since the early 1990's, Mr. Bernstein said, the number of software and information technology jobs in New York City has plummeted in the last five years. How much, he added, is not entirely clear. 
 The New York State Labor Department has estimated that the number of jobs at New York City companies specializing in computer systems design and related services totaled 50,000 in November 2000, but was 33,000 to 34,000 in November 2002, 2003 and 2004. It was estimated at 35,000 two months ago. 
 Such companies, however, employ fewer than half the computer specialists in the city, the department's statistics indicate. Many are employed by financial institutions, communications companies, government agencies and other organizations, and their numbers are more difficult to track, Mr. Bernstein said. 
 In any case, the Labor Department has estimated that the overall number of computer specialists and systems managers in the city will grow to 127,000 in 2012 from 103,000 in 2002.
 The training courses, offered on two levels, were drawn up by the City University of New York's Institute for Software Design and Development, which also provides the instruction. 
 An advanced level, completed so far by more than 450 people, is for workers like Mr. Coello, who attend on their company's time to improve their skills. These courses are short but intensive, usually running 25 to 35 hours over a week, covering topics that have included building and deploying firewalls, managing software projects and working with XML, a Web standard that facilitates data sharing across systems.
 An intermediate level, completed by nearly 80 people, is mostly for those seeking their first job in the industry and for those who have been displaced because their skills are obsolete. These courses, running several months, include topics like designing and developing Web-based applications using the Java programming language, and installing and maintaining servers, the computers that provides services like e-mail routing to other computers on a network. 
 Mr. Bernstein said that the federal grant paying for the program would run out in April, and that his group was looking for alternative financing. One possibility, he said, is having companies share the cost of the advanced courses. 
 Two more advanced course are scheduled with the remaining grant money, both starting in February, and have openings. Their subjects are described on his group's Web site, nysia.org. Further intermediate courses -- students in the latest will graduate Jan. 31 -- will be scheduled when new financing is arranged, Mr. Bernstein said. 
 The program, which has no beginner courses, has included efforts to help the intermediate students get jobs, and many have been placed with organizations like I.B.M. and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, he said.
 Mr. Ruggiero, 24, a Brooklyn resident, said recently that he had been unable to land a job in the computer industry despite a computer science degree earned at Hunter College, from which he graduated in 2004. He realized, he said, that the kind of companies he hoped to work for ''want to see that you have hands-on knowledge of the Windows environment, especially the Windows Server environment,'' which he had not been taught in college.
 So after passing the aptitude test for the intermediate program, he signed up for classes that included instruction in the Microsoft Windows Server System. Now, as a network engineer with Corporate Power, a technology management consulting company in Manhattan, ''the majority of work I do is on Windows Server,'' he said.
 Ms. Reynolds, a 30-year-old Manhattan resident, graduated from City College two years ago with a major in computer science. After working as an intern in computer programming at General Electric, she decided that her next step would be learning Java, so she took a course in the group's program.
 Though she does not use Java in her current job as a program analyst with ALLSector Technology Group, a Manhattan consulting company, knowing the language, she said, will be valuable for a future job.
 Mr. Coello, 27, from Staten Island, was already working as a database specialist at Metis Associates, a consulting company in Manhattan, when he took an advanced course. He had been working with databases built and managed with the Microsoft Access system, but to work with larger databases, he said, he had to learn a more comprehensive system, Microsoft SQL Server.
 So at his boss's suggestion, he said, he took the course on Microsoft SQL, and ''it enabled me to get into more advanced and bigger projects at my company.''

HEADLINE: The Independent Drugstore Goes the Way of the Soda Fountain

BYLINE: By JANE GORDON

 BODY:
ON the Internet, a search for Kaye's Pharmacy and Home Healthcare in Meriden turns up this advertisement: ''Kaye's Pharmacy. Your real neighborhood drugstore.''
 The virtual Kaye's may be a neighborhood drugstore, but the real Kaye's was bought by CVS in 2003. And it is just another on a long list of independent drugstores in the state that have been taken over by chains, showing how Connecticut has become a microcosm of the battle between the mammoths of the drug industry: Walgreens and CVS, and to a lesser degree their smaller competitors, including Brooks Pharmacy and Rite Aid.
 Hardly a month goes by that a local planning and zoning commission does not see a proposal for another store, even if the town already has two or three within striking distance. Add to that the pharmacies in the local Shaw's and Stop & Shop, and drugstores seem to be flooding the landscape. 
 But the perception belies a more complex reality: Connecticut has fewer pharmacies than it did 14 years ago, and certain areas remain underserved. The chains have undeniably grown in the state. Walgreens, which operates 5,000 stores nationwide, has 53 in Connecticut, and it plans to open 10 more this year and 10 more in 2007. CVS, with 5,300 stores nationwide, operates 132 in Connecticut. 
 Yet some independent drugstores are fighting back, trying to find new ways to capitalize on their traditional strengths of customer service and personal interaction. 
 In 2005, there were 645 drugstores in Connecticut, according to state figures, said Margherita R. Giuliano, the executive vice president of the Connecticut Pharmacists Association. Of these, 479 were chain stores and 166 were independents, she said. 
 Fourteen years ago, there were 743 pharmacies in the state, she said. Of that number, 265 were chains, and 478 were independent. From 1992 to 1996, the independents closed at a faster rate than the chains grew, falling victim to competition, higher costs and lower insurance-reimbursement rates.
 ''That's a pretty staggering number when you think that's the number of businesses that closed in one industry in a four-year period,'' Ms. Giuliano said, ''and we're a small state.'' 
 She witnessed the effect firsthand. George Loalbo, her uncle, and his partner, Frank Bonelli, were the owners of Tunxis Pharmacy in West Hartford when a CVS store opened next door. The two drugstores shared a parking lot. 
 When the partners were ready to retire, they could not find a buyer. ''Uncle George ended up having to sell to CVS because nobody could afford to purchase his pharmacy,'' Ms. Giuliano said. ''Independent pharmacies are the real community pharmacy. Their owners live in the community, give to the community. They're the ones who sponsor the Little League teams. People forget these little businesses are a big part of their tax bases.''
 The loss of the independent drugstores in conjunction with the growth of the big chain drugstores has spawned new critics who say that convenience has trumped community, and in turn, that communities will end up paying in the future.
 ''Often when these stores come in, they are touted as job creators or tax-revenue creators, but studies show that's not the case,'' said Stacy Mitchell, the author of ''The Big-Box Swindle: The True Cost of Mega-Retailers and How Citizens Can Fight Back'' (Beacon Press, 2006). She is also the senior researcher for the Institute for Self-Reliance in Minneapolis, a nonprofit organization that is an advocate for community-oriented economic development.
 The institute did a study in Maine that tracked the dollars spent at locally owned businesses. ''Those businesses then spent their money locally,'' Ms. Mitchell said. ''But much of the dollars that go into a CVS leaves the local economy. And there are many other things -- quality of life, the value of being a unique place that helps draw entrepreneurs, the importance of local investment. There is a civic value to the kinds of social economic webs that you don't see in a place where the business is headquartered elsewhere.'' 
 Mike DeAngelis, a spokesman for CVS, said the company's business model is based on customer convenience.
 ''CVS offers multiple convenient locations,'' he said. ''Any CVS customer can use any CVS pharmacy, the pharmacy is open late at night or even 24 hours to handle emergency prescriptions, we have automated phone lines where customers can call in and have their prescriptions ready when promised, and CVS has drive-through pharmacy service. Having said that, I want to reiterate that our pharmacists live and work in the community, just as pharmacists who work for the independent drugstores do.''
 Daniel Tuba is the town planner in Monroe, a town of not quite 20,000, where several chain drugstores have opened in the commercial district, and more are on the way.
 ''They probably offer a lot of things to people who are looking for convenience,'' Mr. Tuba said. ''People run in and grab a quick item or two. These stores fill that niche. Instead of somebody traveling to a big-box store someplace, they can just get the basic needs there.''
 In Glastonbury, the town's Plan and Zoning Commission denied an application by CVS to remove almost 6,000 truckloads of dirt from a hillside to make way for a new building. The town already has two CVS stores and a Stop & Shop pharmacy; a Walgreens is going up, and another CVS is in East Hartford, just over the town's border. But Patricia Low, a member of the commission, said the decisions of the agency are based on the facts of each case.
 ''We live in a capitalist society,'' Ms. Low said. ''We're not there to legislate whether there are 6 shoe stores or 12 shoe stores. We look at the regulations and the proposal there in front of us and how it fits the property.''
 On its Web site, Walgreens boasts that it opens a new store every 20 hours. When asked why Walgreens opens so many of its stores within a stone's throw of a CVS, Michael Polzin, a Walgreens spokesman, said, ''I wouldn't say that's the goal, but certainly we compete with them in markets across the country.''
 ''We do not locate a store simply based on where our competition is,'' he said. ''Certainly how the market is currently being served is one of the factors, but it's one of dozens of factors.''
 Mr. DeAngelis of CVS said: ''The markets that we are entering now are new and growing markets in terms of population growth and rise in elderly population.''
 ''We are moving where the population is moving,'' he explained. ''When we open a new store in Connecticut, it's more likely to be a relocation.''
 Mr. DeAngelis did not have a projection for new stores or relocations for CVS in Connecticut for the next year, saying the company was always seeking new opportunities. 
 The growth of the chain stores, along with other business pressures, has proponents of independent drugstores lobbying Congress for passage of the Community Pharmacy Preservation Act, which seeks to change antitrust laws to allow independent pharmacists to negotiate terms and conditions of insurance contracts as a collective unit. 
 Ms. Giuliano said: ''I think we're seeing a change in congressional recognition -- that it's critical to keep these independents in the mix. Without help, they're not going to be able to be in the mix with the pressures coming from the reimbursements and the costs of doing business.''
 Dan Lupariello's father opened Lupe's Pharmacy on Main Street in Bridgeport, two blocks from St. Vincent's Hospital, in 1946. His father eventually turned the business over to Mr. Lupariello. Recently, he talked about the changes he has seen, including the emergence of mail-order prescriptions and the massing of the chains.
 ''They're surrounding me,'' he said, laughing. ''They build them every mile or two. Initially, they didn't hurt my business, but now that they build so many stores, it has thinned out some of the new business I could probably get.''
 Still, Mr. Lupariello is a legend to his customers, including Deborah Moye, whose husband is a dialysis patient. 
 ''There aren't words to describe Danny or his staff,'' Mrs. Moye said. ''The people are absolutely phenomenal. I used to use the chains, but I don't anymore. I like the pharmacy that has a private owner and personalized service.'' 
 While the old-time corner drugstore was compact -- with space for the pharmacist, a couple of rows of isopropyl alcohol and bandages, and possibly a luncheon counter -- the new generation of chain drugstores is a spinoff of the old five-and-dime store, with a huge selection. Besides full-service photo processing, they offer rows of detergent, milk, eggs, paper goods of all kinds, toiletries, makeup, perfume, decorative items for whatever holiday is at hand, and in the rear, the pharmacy.
 Their demands for increasing amounts of space has drawn opposition in some localities, including West Hartford, where residents sued and lost to Walgreens in an effort to stop the Art Deco Elm Theater from becoming a drugstore. In Windsor Locks, several residents on Elm Street are appealing the town planning and zoning commission's approval of a Walgreens, contending it would harm their quality of life. That store is to be built close to a CVS.
 The big chains are not necessarily going into areas that need more pharmacies. Often, they move in across the street from an existing drugstore, like the CVS that sits across from Kerr's Village Pharmacy in Old Greenwich.
 In Monroe, all of the independent drugstores are gone. ''There's probably a lot of intangibles with that loss, in my mind the biggest loss being the personal touch and the personal relationships.'' said Mr. Tuba, the town planner. ''I hate to use this phrase, but it was the good old days: the druggist knew you, and you knew the druggist. You could have that conversation about medically related things and drug-related things. Now, when you go into a chain pharmacy, you look at the plaques listing the pharmacist on duty, and there are three of four names. Go back the next day, there are three of four different names.''
 Yet in Beacon Falls, a town in western New Haven County with 5,246 residents, just a quarter of the population of Monroe, there was no drugstore until two months ago. Then, in a move that went against the trend, Marion Bradley, a pharmacist, and her husband, Bob, a businessman, opened the independent Beacon Falls Pharmacy in the town's tiny commercial district, where it has joined a grocery store, a couple of gas stations, a tavern and a package store. 
 In a throwback to earlier days, the Bradleys are listed in the telephone book, just in case somebody needs them after hours, which somebody did recently -- the Bradleys drove down to their store, opened up and filled an emergency prescription. 
 ''We fill a little niche,'' said Mr. Bradley, who grew up in Beacon Falls. ''Seymour and Naugatuck next door have tons of chains, but we have none. That's been our selling point. We're getting a sense that our customers are kind of tired of the chains. Anyone who is in town has to make a 20-minute trip to get their prescriptions. So we save folks some time, and we do free deliveries. In an emergency, we're here for anybody who needs us.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Dan Lupariello, the owner and pharmacist at Lupe's Pharmacy in Bridgeport, waiting on Deborah Moye, above. HEADLINE: Fair Ball

BYLINE: By Andrew Zimbalist. 
Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College, is the author of the forthcoming ''In the Best Interests of Baseball? The Revolutionary Reign of Bud Selig.''

 BODY:
PLANS to build a new Yankee Stadium in the South Bronx have kicked up a small storm of local protest. Many people who live near Mullaly and Macombs Dam Parks, where the new stadium will be built, are concerned about what it will mean for their neighborhood, and rightfully so. But the crucial public policy question here is whether there will be a net benefit for residents of the Bronx and the other boroughs. The answer is yes. 
 Those who want no disruption and the maintenance of the status quo need to think again. The existing stadium was built in 1923 and grows more unsafe and expensive to maintain with each year. The Yankees have been spending nearly $10 million a year on maintenance at Yankee Stadium -- money that their lease allows them to deduct from the rent they pay the city. Engineering studies say it's time to build a new stadium. 
The Yankees are proposing a fair financial deal to the city. Nationally, during the last 15 years, the public share in stadium development costs (that is, the stadium plus roads, utilities and so forth) for professional sports has averaged around 75 percent. The Yankees are planning to spend $800 million of their own money on the new stadium (no major league baseball team has spent more than $300 million on their own playing field). The city and state together will spend about $210 million for improvements in the neighborhood. By this reckoning, the public share is only about 21 percent.
 Yet most of this public spending will be of direct benefit to the community, and a significant share will come back to the state and city. As part of the $210 million, the city will spend a projected $130 million to replace and upgrade the parks and their athletic facilities. According to the plan, there will be 10 percent more park space, more ball fields, an upgrade to the existing running track and soccer field and the addition of basketball, handball and tennis courts. 
 Contrary to some reports, these fields will be at ground level. Other than the new tennis center, which will be on the river (part of a 5.5-acre riverfront park with esplanade and bubble for winter use), the fields and open space are linked, and adjacent to the new stadium. Together with the development of surrounding commercial space and the prospect for a new Metro-North platform, the project will be a major facelift for the area and help gentrify the South Bronx.
 Also part of the $210 million is the state's investment of $70 million into new parking garages. Under the proposal, all parking revenue would go back to the state and more than pay off the investment. The city and state would each contribute $5 million toward other improvements.
 Further, the city will be able to sell off all the seats and other memorabilia from the present Yankee Stadium, lowering its net cost on the project. The Yankees are also agreeing to cover any cost overruns on the new stadium.
 Naysayers will object that the Yankees contemplate getting a substantial part of the construction financing from tax-exempt bonds issued by a new local development corporation. Debt service on these bonds will be covered by the Yankees via payments in lieu of taxes to the corporation. The critics will argue that if the Yankees cover the debt service instead of paying taxes, then, in effect, the public treasury is paying for the bonds and the stadium through forfeited tax collections. 
 This objection was valid in the case of the vetoed West Side stadium for the Jets, but it applies only to a small degree to the Yankees project. The Bronx is already in a tax abatement zone -- commercial developers in the borough don't pay real estate taxes on new projects for 15 years. 
 So while it could be argued that in net terms, the Yankees are contributing only $756 million to the new stadium and not $800 million, the team is still paying 75 percent of the total project costs.
 All major investment projects, no matter how positive they may be for a community, disrupt the life of somebody. Undoubtedly, some residents will be made worse off. But as an investment, the Yankees' stadium plan is a winner for the Bronx and all of New York.

HEADLINE: Mott Street Blues

BYLINE: By RICHARD MORGAN. 
E-mail: streetlevel@nytimes.com

 BODY:
IN Philip Lam's office, at Green City Realty on Market Street near the Manhattan Bridge, a picture of a property under renovation is pinned to the wall. The two-bedroom condo has huge windows, pristine hardwood floors and an airy luxury that gives the space the look of a SoHo loft.
 But this attractive posting has people in Chinatown worried. The condo sits not in SoHo but at 173-5 East Broadway, right in their neighborhood. The other 28 condos under development in the 60,000-square-foot building are no less luxe, and will variously offer 18-foot ceilings, four exposures and gas fireplaces, and carry price tags of $600,000 to $5 million. 
In an odd juxtaposition, crowded, workaday Chinatown is surrounded by some of Manhattan's poshest neighborhoods, such as SoHo and TriBeCa. If those areas begin to spill over on them, Chinatown residents fear, they may be priced out of their own neighborhood. Many manufacturers have already moved to cheaper locations, like Sunset Park, Brooklyn; Mr. Lam and other real estate agents also report a recent uptick in the number residential buyers who are not of Chinese descent.
 The resentment is growing, among nonresidents who treasure the area's character and, especially, local residents who feel invaded. ''This is not for the outside world,'' Zhihao Song, a 32-year-old garment worker, said. ''This is for the Chinese people.'' The other day, as he picked with chapped hands through exotic produce at an open market under the Manhattan Bridge, he asked, ''What can you call Chinatown if the Chinese people cannot live here?''
 The lure of Chinatown grew this month, when Gov. George E. Pataki designated it as one of the first of a dozen new economic Empire Zones. The program grants a mix of tax benefits to encourage development. 
 ''It's just supply and demand, very simple,'' Dean Lui, the owner of Century 21 New Golden Age, a real estate firm at Chatham Square, said of Chinatown's allure. ''We are a lot cheaper than TriBeCa and just a few blocks away. It makes a lot of sense.'' 
 But this surge of buyers and investors cannot be easily absorbed with more buildings; Chinatown is cramped as it is. As a result, condo prices in Chinatown have soared, from about $450 a square foot in 2004 to about $700 a square foot today. Mr. Lui, who handles higher-end condos, said he had seen the average cost go from $860 a square foot two years ago to $1,100 now.
 Mr. Lam, who has sold real estate in the area for 17 years, makes the best of the situation by working as a Mandarin-speaking middleman for the new non-Chinese owners of eight rental buildings, all residential. ''For every 20 Chinese buyers in Chinatown, there is just one American buyer,'' he said. ''But two, three years ago, that was one American for every 50 Chinese buyers.'' Mr. Lui, for his part, estimated that over the past few years, the Chinese stake in Chinatown ownership has fallen to 75 percent from 90 percent.
 Mr. Lam said of the change: ''This is America, so it doesn't surprise me too much. If I could buy buildings, I could either buy one building in SoHo that will go up a little bit in value over the next five years, or I could buy five buildings in Chinatown that might double in value.'' 
 John Kuo Wei Tchen, a history professor at New York University who specializes in Chinese immigration, has a different calculus. Development has been a ''neutron bomb,'' he said, that has reduced other ethnic enclaves to building facades, tourist traps and memorial plaques. He fears the same will happen in Chinatown. 
 ''To me, Chinatown is one of the few remaining real Manhattan neighborhoods,'' Dr. Tchen said. ''It's not just a facade here. You look around and what do you see? Little Italy is gone. The Jewish Lower East Side is gone. Even Harlem is fading. But Chinatown survives as the real thing. It's a living community.''
 If the signs are grim, Chinatown optimists can point to at least one sunnier fact. Chinese New Year, which begins on Jan. 29, will usher in the Year of the Dog. It is said to be a much luckier time than the current Year of the Rooster.

HEADLINE: A Place for Sex Offenders

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki has proposed turning a woodsy upstate prison into a pseudo-prison for certain convicted sex offenders who have already done their time. His impulse is understandable: rather than allow men who seem likely to repeat terrible crimes back onto the street, why not lock them up for psychiatric treatment until they get their impulses under control? The United States Supreme Court has declared the practice permissible for people deemed ''mentally abnormal,'' and 16 other states have so-called civil-confinement laws.
 But it isn't necessary to be a raging civil libertarian to be queasy about the Pataki plan, under which the state would spend $130 million to raze and replace Camp Pharsalia, 50 miles north of Binghamton, with a new treatment center run by the State Office of Mental Health. 
There will never be an easy or wholly satisfying solution to the problem of violent sexual criminals. Sickened by highly publicized crimes against children and dubious about the odds of rehabilitation, Congress and the states have been adopting ever-tougher laws governing where and how sex offenders can live, work and travel. 
 But peace of mind has been elusive. An era that began with laws requiring freed sex offenders to register with local law-enforcement officials now features laws requiring notification of neighbors when offenders move in, the posting of offenders' names on the Web, electronic monitoring and restrictive ''distance laws'' meant to keep them away from places like schools and parks. 
 Preventive detention for violent sex offenders is the natural end point of the logic embraced by Mr. Pataki and his allies: that these are a special class of misfits whom existing laws are incapable of subduing, and that no price is too high for safety. But while no one disputes society's obligation to protect the innocent, it is fair to ask whether the state's limited resources might be better deployed at the front end of the problem. A bill sponsored in the Assembly by Speaker Sheldon Silver and Joseph Lentol, while allowing for the civil confinement of sexual predators, places a heavier emphasis on treatment behind bars. The current prison treatment system, underfunded and understaffed, typically offers six months of group therapy run by corrections officials. The Assembly bill would require at least two years of treatment by mental health professionals for everyone imprisoned for a felony sex offense, and provide for continued treatment after release. 
 But treatment is not the entire answer. Few would deny that the universe of sex criminals includes a small number of repeat offenders who do not respond to therapy, and that the criminal-justice system will eventually run out of ways to deal with them. The admittedly imperfect answer in that case would be to seek longer sentences for violent sex crimes to reduce the chances that dangerous predators will be released too soon, and to aggressively monitor offenders upon release with electronic bracelets and a strengthened parole system.
 Psychiatric treatment in prisons, intensive outpatient therapy and close monitoring are, in the main, preferable to a questionable reliance on preventive detention. The remaking of Camp Pharsalia, in fact, seems more like an upstate jobs program. We should not forget that only last year lawmakers were urging Mr. Pataki to keep Camp Pharsalia open somehow, lest its neighbors lose 100 jobs and $11 million in economic activity. 
 We are all for upstate development, but the more urgent questions have to do with public safety and whether lavishing resources on a place for warehousing a small subset of sex offenders -- rather than aggressively treating and keeping tabs on a far larger cohort of criminals -- will really make all of us safer, or just make it seem that way.

HEADLINE: New at E.R.'s: More Sense Of Urgency

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: Cortland Manor 

 BODY:
IT had all the markings of a typical emergency department waiting room: magazines scattered on end tables; a wall-mounted television; more than two dozen institutional chairs lining the walls. 
 Only the people were missing. On a recent weekday afternoon, the waiting room at the Hudson Valley Hospital Center here was empty. The hospital has adopted a no-wait emergency room procedure. A recent $1 million renovation eliminated the registration desk. A greeter now sends patients to one of three triage rooms. Insurance information is taken at bedside. The department is split into two zones: fast track, for minor injuries and illnesses treatable by nurse practitioners, and critical care.
''Nobody wants to wait for anything anymore,'' said Dr. Raymond Iannaccone, director of the emergency department. ''We have to focus on clinical care, but no-wait is also good medical care.'' 
 The revamped emergency room is among the first in a wave of planned emergency department renovations in the county. Most have similar aims -- to reduce waiting times, expand working space, improve privacy and upgrade technology. 
 White Plains Hospital, which has the busiest emergency room in the county, with 45,000 visits last year, plans a $10 million renovation that will double its size by 2008. Phelps Memorial Hospital, in Sleepy Hollow, just broke ground for a $12 million project that will triple the size of its emergency department.
 Officials at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, which last updated its emergency department in 2000, said that they plan a $7 million expansion, adding space for triage, fast-track and acute-care areas, and a new preadmissions unit for patients awaiting admission that will free more emergency beds. Northern Westchester Hospital, in Mount Kisco, is planning an all-new emergency department, double the size of the current one. Cost estimates run from $13 million to $16 million.
 Sound Shore Medical Center, in New Rochelle, aims to double the size of its emergency department over the next two years. Mount Vernon Hospital has similar plans: officials there hope to open a new $2.7 million department in a year. 
 And at Hudson Valley Hospital Center here, the expansion isn't yet finished; more work is planned, at a cost of about $8 million, hospital administrators say.
 Several factors are driving this trend, the first of which is an overall increase in the number of emergency visits. Jon Schandler, president of White Plains Hospital, said that emergency room visits there increased by 8.8 percent last year. Hudson Valley Hospital had a 10.7 percent increase over that period. Similarly, Lawrence Hospital, which had 25,000 visits in 1993, had 34,000 last year. 
 These increases have various causes, said Daniel Sisto, president of the Healthcare Association of New York State, which represents hospitals, nursing homes and other providers, and president of the State Medical Society, which represents doctors. One reason, he said, is that because Medicaid reimbursements are low, many doctors simply tell their sick patients to go to the emergency room for treatment. 
 The growing number of uninsured people adds to the pressure on emergency rooms, too, because they turn to the emergency rooms for non-emergency ailments, but even privately insured people are being seen there, because their doctors, needing to meet minimum quotas of patient visits per hour to maintain profitability, cannot afford to see too many time-consuming sick patients. 
 The aging of the population has also increased demand for emergency room space, according to experts. Once at the emergency room, elderly people tend to stay a lot longer, because their medical problems are more complicated. ''Ninety-two-year-old people with abdominal pain and a list of 15 medicines they're on, that's not going to be a 20-minute visit,'' said Joel Seligman, president and chief executive of Northern Westchester Hospital. ''That's going to be hours of observation, a CAT scan, a lot of lab work, and it's going to take up one of those beds for hours. Years ago, we might have taken mom or dad to the doctor's office on a Thursday afternoon. These days, if you call, they're going to say 'Take her to the E.R.' ''
 More pressure comes from hospital closings. Whenever hospitals close, emergency rooms in other hospitals tend to pick up the slack, and in Westchester in 2003, the closing of two community hospitals -- United Hospital Medical Center in Port Chester and St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains -- added pressure to the remaining emergency departments, particularly at White Plains Hospital. 
 Throw in a general nursing shortage, a surge in substance abuse and the fallout from deinstitutionalizing mentally ill patients in the 1980's and 1990's, Mr. Sisto said, and it is not surprising that emergency departments are at capacity. In addition, the emergency departments help out when there is a logjam elsewhere in a hospital; much of the monitoring equipment in the intensive care unit can also be found in emergency, and acutely ill patients can be held there.
 YET despite all these factors, investing millions of dollars in emergency departments does not seem to make sense at first glance. Hospitals in New York State have been losing money for seven years, according to the Healthcare Association of New York State, which represents hospitals, nursing homes and other health care providers, and emergency departments tend to be money losers. They are expensive to run, with high-tech equipment and intensive staffing, and many patients they treat don't need such high-level care.
 But hospitals are making the investment because the emergency department is the portal for admissions, as well as the first impression many people get of the hospital. ''E.R.'s tend not to be profitable on a per se basis, if you look at it as a revenue center,'' said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. ''However, where the equation changes is that half the admissions on the inpatient side come in from the emergency department, so from the hospital economic point of view, having a top-drawer emergency department is tantamount to having a good hospital.''
 In 2003, the most recent year for which figures are available, 48 percent of all Westchester hospital admissions came through an emergency room, according to the hospital association. At Phelps, 67 percent of patients were admitted through the emergency department; at Lawrence, the figure was 50 percent, and at Hudson Valley it was ''close to 70 percent,'' said John C. Federspiel, president of the hospital.
 Having an efficient, patient-friendly emergency department is also an important marketing tool, hospital administrators say. 
 ''It's the first contact, certainly, for people who are new in the community, and particularly those with young families,'' said Keith Safian, the chief operating officer at Phelps. ''Our whole focus here is to eliminate all the anxieties about something everyone hates: going to the emergency room and waiting.''
 The plans at Phelps include eliminating the standard all-purpose waiting room. Instead, patients will be taken to a private treatment space for triage and treatment. The 30 private rooms will have telephones, televisions and chairs for visitors, although there will be a larger family waiting area for relatives who prefer that. Pediatric patients and their families will have a separate area, with a playroom.
 Several hospitals already have a greeter or ombudsman who acts almost like a concierge, keeping patients informed of how far along they are in their treatment, and sometimes providing coffee or cookies. 
 ''Many people do not understand why someone else is taken when they've been waiting for four hours, and in the meantime we may have had four ambulances coming in with cardiac arrests,'' said Heather Morrison, vice president for development and marketing at Lawrence Hospital, which hired a greeter in 2004. ''If your child is 3 years old and has a cut and is crying or bleeding, you're anxious. A greeter will let that person know what is happening.''
 Similarly, White Plains Hospital has two patient representatives to communicate with families. 
 ''Everyone is vulnerable and nobody wants to be there,'' said Mr. Schandler, the White Plains Hospital president. ''The biggest problem is, people don't have the information they need. People are willing to wait, at least if they know that lab work is being done or we had a more critical patient come in.''
 The new emergency department at White Plains will have dedicated spaces for chest-pain patients, stroke victims and children, he said. There will be a large fast-track area so that patients who are not critically ill can move through more quickly. In addition to curtains, there will be glass partitions, which provide more privacy for conversations. All the renovations include plans for increased privacy, upgraded technology and expanded fast track areas. 
 But even as they expand, hospitals are keeping an eye on demographics. Residential construction in the White Plains area is booming. Mr. Federspiel, of Hudson Valley Hospital, said there are 3,000 new units of housing being built in the hospital's catchment area.
 Near Phelps, three different developments under way will add more than 1,700 households to the area. Hospital administrators also point to the trend of retirees choosing to stay in Westchester rather than move.
 ''We are trying to build our new emergency department so that 10 years from now, when the 30 private rooms are not enough for the community, we can expand again,'' said Mr. Safian of Phelps.

HEADLINE: Key to Health-Club Vigor: Stay Limber 

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP

 BODY:
HEALTH clubs and gyms have not had an easy time lately in Westchester: A middling economy has put a damper on some companies' growth; others have seen business siphoned off by the rapid incursion of national chains like Curves, which offer quickie workouts at relatively modest prices. 
 Fitness companies seem to be responding by taking their own advice: Stay flexible. Those already established in the county have been making themselves more available by adding outlets, some aimed at specific subsets of fitness buffs. 
Last March, for example, Altheus opened a high-intensity cycling and endurance facility just a half-mile from its main performance and training fitness center in Rye. The new place is partly a retail store, but also a performance laboratory where cyclists can hook their bikes up to computers to simulate some 300 bicycle race courses, like the Tour de France. 
 Club Fit, on the other hand, has been trying to give its clubs more of a resortlike air, by adding features like larger pools and more children's activities. Together, its two locations -- one in Briarcliff Manor, the other in Jefferson Valley -- have 600 to 700 children a week on their client lists.
 According to Harvey Lauer, president of American Sports Data, a sports market-research company in Hartsdale, certain segments of the public may be riper targets for fitness providers. Health club membership nationwide has grown 138 percent over all since 1987, but among those older than 55, it has grown 563 percent; among those under 18, the number amounts to 230 percent. 
 ''The fitness industry is a tricky business,'' Mr. Lauer said in a recent interview, ''but senior fitness is still a hot button within the industry, as is kids' fitness.'' 
 So far, only a few commercial health clubs here have made a concerted effort to lure the over-55 set, but children's fitness has picked up support. Velocity Sports, for example, offers training, in very small groups, for children 8 to 18. And Bill Beck, a Club Fit owner, says that over the next five years his company will pursue competitive sports training for children.
 In Westchester, Mr. Lauer estimates, there are now about 80 commercial health and fitness clubs in Westchester, with some 75,000 members. But that number seems to be growing. 
 Over the past year New York Sports Clubs has opened three clubs in the county. In September it opened its largest Westchester club to date: a sleek 56,000-square-foot facility on the roof of the City Center in White Plains. 
 Judy Taylor, a spokeswoman for Equinox, which already has clubs in Scarsdale and Mamaroneck, says the company is looking aggressively to expand in the area.
 Expansion is also on the cards for Velocity Sports Performance, based near Atlanta, which already has 62 centers nationwide, and The Gym, based in Montvale, N.J. Both companies are now opening their first clubs in Westchester, on Business Park Drive in Armonk. And Velocity has already sold the rights to two more clubs within the county to a local franchisee, Brian Fee. 
 Club Fit, for its part, is in negotiations with three local condominium developers on plans to manage their fitness facilities. 
 Convenience is another way to win customers, and New York Sports Clubs, whose parent company is Town Sports International, has so far put about half its Westchester clubs into local shopping centers. 
 Partnerships can also help profitability. Altheus opened its main facility in Rye three years ago, but lately it has been busy trying to spread its personalized approach to fitness by partnering with other clubs -- some here in Westchester, some in Manhattan. 
 Last fall, it began offering services at the West End Sports and Aquatic Center, on West 63rd Street in Manhattan, where it runs a training center for triathletes, and it has already partnered with Sports and Fitness Ventures, a Mamaroneck company that operates throughout New York City, to start a cycling and endurance center near Union Square. 
 In Westchester, meanwhile, Altheus is working to take its services to The Club @ 800 Squash & Fitness, a Rye Brook-based company that specializes in corporate fitness and high-performance squash. 
 To Dr. Tom Crawford, Altheus's founder, this kind of expansion makes sense. ''We don't want to go into the real estate business, nor do we want to have a cookie-cutter approach,'' he said. ''Still, we want to extend our business model, so partnering makes sense.''

 A cyclist, top, at Altheus in Rye. Clients using fitness machines, above, at New York Sports Club in White Plains, which has an indoor swimming pool, right. (Photographs by Suzy Allman for The New York Times)
